This pen has so many things going for it, over and above its use by NASA and association with the Apollo missions and Space Program. It really does write beautifully. And the presurized thixotropic ink does an outstanding job when you're writing on clipboards or standing up, or on material that would be hard for most pens' ink to adhere to.

Then there's the design aesthetic and build quality. The chrome-plated design just feels like classic Americana: 50's era drive throughs and heavily chromed classic cars, and the heft and weight of a thing solidly built. Plus the side retraction mechanism is just quirky enough to give the pen a bit of added character and the grippy grooves at the end of the pen are a nice touch, both in terms of design and function.

And finally, yes, there's the undeniable cool factor in owning the original and still-current issue pen for astronauts.

You get all this for just under $30, which is a bargain in my opinion, especially if you're into pens like I am. Recommended.
summary: Flawless Function and Classic All-American Design

Firstly, people should know that this pen is a marker type pen. Since the whole tip is marker-type, it's hard to guess how this will hold up long term, or if you end up getting bolder lines the more you use it (like a standard marker). I've never had this particular brand and model of pen before, so I can't answer long-term use questions.

I bought these pens because I wanted to write notes on post-it notes and stick them to my computer monitor, and have them be easily readable at a glance. I could've used sharpies, but they stink, and though I own lots of "inky" pens, none of them produced a line that was quite thick enough as it's normal width (without going over it twice or more, or writing very slowly to get more ink). I also tried fine tip markers, but they wrote just a tiny bit too thick, so that the letters were harder to read. I bought these hoping to hit the sweet spot between pens and markers, and as it turns out, that's exactly what I got with these.

This pen produces a line close to what you'd expect of a 1.0 mm pen (something probably around 75-85% of a mm for the actual line). This means you'll get nice, bold lines, but not so bold that it should start to loose readability, like with some fine tip markers. Also, being marker type pens, you don't have to worry about the skipping ink issues and so forth that you have with ordinary pens, which is a must for those who love to write, or do a lot of it.

As for comfort of use, that will probably depend on the user.

The pens have a totally smooth plastic body, with no grip, that gets skinnier until it gets to the point. So if you think that a grip-less, totally smooth plastic pen will be a problem for you, you might want to reconsider. Personally, I don't see this being a problem for me, at least... but then I don't plan to write pages with it. If I did, I probably would opt for something with a grip, because I could see this being a problem if you were trying to use it to write pages of text. But for quick notes, it should be fine.

So far, I'd give these five stars, and unless the tips wear down a lot, I'd probably get these again! They should be just perfect for what I wanted them for!
summary: Perfect for what I needed them for!

I called Customer Service and was told of my options: Call Tech Support with my claim, which charges a flat fee of $20; have it repaired "out of warranty," for $100; or, as Handspring's website suggests,
"Sometimes the cost of repairing an older device is almost as much as purchasing a new one. We welcome you to explore your options: maybe it makes more sense to simply buy a new device of the same type, or even treat yourself to the latest & greatest..."
Thanks, Handspring, I've explored my options--and I'm switching to Sony.
summary: Great product...until you try to have it repaired

This is a pretty standard 3-ring binder. While it's not exactly flimsy, I'd by no means "heavy duty." This is one of those binders wherein the rings are attached not to the center of the folder, but to the back of the back flap. In theory, this should make it easier to turn pages and really get use out of the full inch the ring offers.

There were a few things that bothered me about this binder right off the bat, though. First, it has clear plastic windows on the front, back, and spine. This would be great except for the fact that the plastic is rather loose. Even the insert with the product information slips around (and out) easily when you just turn the binder upside down. Likewise, the white plastic that covers the cardboard which makes the cover is bubbled. While this is primarily visible on the inside, it makes the binder look rather cheap (there is one particularly large bubble on the front inside cover that annoys me to no end.

Despite the surface flaws, the binder is quite sturdy and has held up well to being carted back and forth and being opened and closed many, many times. The rings, so far, haven't gone askew, and that's probably the most important thing in any binder. At present, Amazon lists this binder at almost twice the cost of a comparable Avery binder. That being said, I'd rather have the Avery.
summary: Not Terrible, But Not Worth a Premium Price Tag

We buy them by the box! Does anyone ever remember what we did without Sharpies? I would rather use a Sharpie than a pen. We use them in several pen tip sizes and we buy them by the box of 12. Each pen size has its own benefit but they all feature permanent ink for most surfaces. The fine tip is good for marking on boxes and writing on CDs and DVDs you make. The ink is permanent, fast drying and water resistant but you can take it off some surfaces with rubbing alcohol. (Especially right after you write on something with it like a CD.)

We write the purchase date on stored food items or medicine bottles and boxes to always use the oldest first. We also mark the spare packages of batteries with the expiration date to use the older ones first. There are limitless uses for these permanent marking pens. We have used other types of pens but the Sharpies have the best pen tips and last the longest. Just keep the cap on after you are done. We love these pens and they are in every drawer of the house.

I have attached a photo of the three pen tip sizes we use and a line drawn with each one to help you decide which size to buy, we purchased all of them.
summary: My favorite writing tool, what did we do without them?

The process is not as easy as they make it sound, but the ink works, and the Continuous Ink System is the only way to go.  There is a little inconvenience, but it is far preferable to paying $20 per cartridge and changing them frequently.  That being said, let's look at the ink refill kit.

First, it works. However, you will need some supplies before you start the process.
1.  Latex gloves, at least 6 pairs, preferably about 20 gloves.  I like the Liberty T2800W, from Amazon.
2.  A box of tissues.
3.  A nail or pipe cleaner.
4.  A side cutter or wire cutter to cut the tips.
5.  Maybe some plastic wrap, like Saran wrap.
6.  Newspaper, or an old towel.
7.  Waste basket with a disposable liner.

Set the CIS on newspaper or an old towel.
Put on a pair of latex gloves.
Unscrew the tip of the first bottle.
Cut the tip about 1/4" from the top, maybe further if necessary.
Use the nail or pipe cleaner to pop the seal out of the plastic tip.  Set it aside.  If you lose it, you will need the plastic wrap.
Remove the stopper (not the air vent) from the CIS tank that matches the ink color.  You should start at one end, either yellow or black.
CAREFULLY squeeze the ink slowly into the tank.  Try not to let a bubble form, as it will overflow onto the tank.  (It will happen anyway; that's why you have a box of tissue.).
When the tank is full enough, turn the bottle upright, remove the plastic cap, put the seal back in the cap, and screw the cap down.  If you lose the seal, cover the top of the bottle with Saran Wrap and then screw the cap back on.
Wipe down the nozzle with a tissue and toss the tissue and your gloves into the waste basket.

Re-glove, so as not to cross-contaminate colors.
Repeat the process with the second color, third color, etc., replacing your gloves every time they get soiled.

Wipe down the CIS tank, especially the rubber feet, as ink will have run down the sides.  Toss the tissues regularly.

Let it all dry on the newspaper for a while, then wipe the tank to be sure there is no more ink on it.  Toss out the trash.

Good luck.
summary: It's a Messy Job, But Somebody Has to Do It!

reviewText:
This calculator is just what I wanted and needed. I have owned top of the line graphing calculators from HP, Casio, Sharp, TI, etc., but overall I like this one almost the best due primarily to its simplicity and ease of use. I like it especially for trips and outside activities when I can do quite useful mathematical explorations that I don't normally have time for at home or in the office with my busy schedule. It was designed by HP and teachers, first and foremost however, as an aid in teaching HIGH SCHOOL students mathematics in a very user-friendly manner.

PROS:

1) It is simple, fairly light and quite fast (75 MHz clock speed), algebraic equation operating system (EOS), but not with HP RPN, but not bad for the money since the hp 39gs units are now on sale for $63.99 compared with $59.99 for the new HP 35s for example which is a great machine, but which is totally outclassed by this much more versatile unit. The hp 39 gs is now about one year in production having replaced the 39G+ with a much better designed keyboard, etc. as described below and has evolved through 3-4 flavors from the original HP 38 of about a decade ago).

2) Very well organized analysis activities using special Aplets with about a dozen available with the unit and many many more on the world wide web (or you can write your own since programming is also available on the 39 gs). These specialized Aplets include analysis of functions, parametric equations, the famous HP solver system, statistics, etc. (with least squares curve fits available for about a dozen types, such as cubic, exponential, power law, logistic or even a user defined type, etc.!). The unit also has about 200 kb of available RAM and about 1 Mb of ROM for the operating system which is a lot more than the more powerful hp 48gII for example.

3) It will supply three types of analysis for every problem, namely a numerical table of values, a graphic plot (only two-dimensional types however) and a symbolic analysis which is only completely possible for the simplest Calculus cases (polynomials and basic trig, logarithmic and hyperbolic functions). Nevertheless, it also does numerical differential and integral Calculus and it can even supply a Taylor series approximation for your functions. It can also display a fine split-screen view (side by side) supplying a table of values as well a plot which is also very useful (with many useful zoom options).

4) It also handles some advanced mathematical functions (including hyperbolics, etc.) and of course can be used to analyze complex numbers, lists and matrices and can even take the square root of negative numbers directly in a very straight forward manner (unlike the HP 35s)!

5) It also allows the user to make detailed notes and sketches and also interfaces very nicely with a PC using the USB cable supplied with the unit for exchanging information. It also has an RS-232 (serial) as well as an infrared transfer option available as well.

6) It comes with a well written and well organized 314 page users manual and with an even more advanced manual available on the supplied CD.

7) It has a new Flash ROM so that the calculator can be electronically updated if new EOS software ROM's are produced by HP without changing out the hardware.

8) Date and time is always available with the on-board clock (using the DISPTIME command)

9) The unit has a totally redesigned keyboard that has quite an excellent feel to it (unlike the fiasco's connected with the HP 49g series for example and even better in my humble opinion than the revered HP 50g now in production for over a year too which I also own). The overall unit seems to be very well made and should last a very long time too. As always, the calculator special self tests are excellent and are triggered by simple keystroke commands. Also, Typing RULES or AMIGOS in "Home" produces two "HP easter eggs" of people who were involved in the design and production of this great system.

10) It has a completely scrollable operations history in HOME (unlimited within the available RAM memory and also easy to erase when extra memory is needed) that is very easy to manipulate by using the Copy command to recall previously evaluated expressions in order to perform quick "what-if" analysis, etc.

11) It is also very intuitive to operate in my opinion even without HP RPN. It is a great start to get students and teachers interested in doing more math and science too which is a very good thing considering recent trends in North America.

CONS

1) The batteries only last 65 hours according to HP. I can't confirm this fact as of yet, but it uses 4 AAA batteries as well as a common Lithium battery to be used as a backup while changing the main batteries.

2) It is quite thick in comparison to other such calculators and in spite of the supplied high quality slide-on cover (a maximum total 1.22 inches thick with the cover on for protection), HP should have supplied a good case for further protection as has been its standard for many other of its calculators (including the HP 35s). Why just imitate the other manufacturers with a slide-on cover for its only protection? HP has always gone its own way in this field considering how few people really understand or actively use RPN logic every day (which I have previously always preferred for many years now). Most of us now have easily accessible computers and compilers to do most computing tasks. I usually use a calculator at work only to carefully check intricate computer calculations, but when I do I want it to be simple and easy to use, especially since I don't use it every day.

3) It will not analyze ordinary differential equations as the more advanced calculators can now readily do. Also, the statistical applet correlation coefficient provided is only for a linear curve fit (regardless of the fit assumed). The relative error is provided instead for both the linear as well as for any of the other curve fit options.

4) Hopefully its sister calculator, the HP 40gs (with a full HP Computer Algebra System-CAS) for UNIVERSITY LEVEL will also be released in North America soon. HP has recently combined efforts (as of early May, 2007) with a company in Oregon to use the 39GS and 40GS for routine laboratory measurements at high schools and at universities in the very near future.

This is a box of rubber bands. They do indeed come in a variety of assorted sizes, and appear to made of rubber. I do somewhat question the claim that they are ergonomically correct.... I have placed them on a variety of body parts and found that they do eventually cut off at least some circulation when placed on a body part. Not only that, but the rubberiness tends to tug at my body hair quite a bit, even at some point going so far as to rip it out whole. While this would be perfectly acceptable for an epilator, I'm not exactly sure that this is entirely acceptable for an ergonomically correct rubber band. Perhaps if the rubber band were made out of something other than rubber? A vinyl band, perhaps? Yes, perhaps if it were made out of vinyl it might be a bit more ergonomically correct. reviewText:
We replaced our aging Canon all-in-one printer when the print head broke. The ink costs were very high anyway, so we were glad to see it go.

We replaced it with two printers, this Brother DCP-L2540DW for low cost B&W printing which is 85% of our needs, which is quite fast. To satisfy my wife's artistic needs we also bought the Brother MFC-J880DW compact All-in-One Color printer. Both units installed easily on our WIFI network. My only complaint with both units is small paper tray capacity.

We chose Brother after carefully studying cost of ink and toner compared to other home-office printers of the same class. We already had a very good experience with Brother QL-500 label printer which has served us well for years. The Brothers web site has excellent support for manuals, apps, drivers, etc.
summary: Speedy B&W printer with low toner cost for home-office.

I had stage 3 lower rectal cancer a few years back, and the resulting surgery left me with a lot of pain, discomfort, and other "issues," that made sitting a tortuous affair. No cushion in the world can alleviate ALL pain and discomfort, but I have to say, this one comes pretty darn close. It's amazing how something as simple as providing an "opening" for the coccyx bone can alleviate so much pressure, and it's the pressure that ultimately causes the pain and discomfort. I bought the cushion for my car, originally, and it's really helped me not dread driving as much. I plan to purchase a couple more for around the house. It may seem like an expensive cushion, but the money is well-spent, and the construction is quite durable. But for me, the easing of the pain and discomfort is priceless.
summary: best money spent on any cushion.

reviewText: This ink works exactly as it should.

The good:

+ Beautiful, timeless, sleek, compact design.
+ Good build quality. Feels solid.
+ It really does write sideways and upside down.
+ It really does write on surfaces other pens cannot (e.g. glossy paper, wet paper, etc).
+ It really does write in hot or cold weather.

The bad:

- Ink is lighter in color than other pens (e.g. black is more grayish, and faded).
- Ink is thicker, pen strokes feel more labored, and it's slower to write with than other ballpoints.
- Refills are relatively expensive.
- The pen is so small and slick that it's really easy for it to slip out of your pocket if you don't use the clip, or if you don't secure the clip to something.
- The cuts on the finger grip area do prevent slipping, but they are pretty sharp.

The verdict:

= I'm keeping my Space Pen because it is a neat little pocket pen. But it will never replace my Zebra F-301 for serious writing.
summary: More "cool" than practical, but still very cool

It sounds and feels as if it is having no trouble at all shredding whatever I put into it. To be fair, I never shred more than maybe five layers at a time, just in case but I didn't with the previous one either. I love being able to just pull out the basket to empty it. No having to lift off the heavy top portion as I did with the old one. It is a tiny bit top heavy, but since its basically sits in one spot all the time, it doesn't matter. It was super easy to put the casters on, but it looks as if once they are on, they can't be removed. No matter. I like being able to roll it if I want to. All in all, I really love this shredder and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good sturdy home shredder. Oh yeah, I love the tiny little micro pieces it cuts the paper into.

I usually buy push pins at the dollar store, so these are actually 100% more expensive than the cheaper ones I usually use (as they are currently priced at just under $2). That being said, they are worth the extra cost if you've ever used push pins and found that it hurts your finger to press them into the surface you're attaching them to. If you mainly use a corkboard notice board, then the extra expense isn't worth it. However, I sometimes use push pins in harder surfaces and they are much better for less yielding surfaces.

The pin portion (metallic projection) is also thicker than cheap push pins and is less likely to snap off or bend under increased pressure. I have, on occasion, used push pins to "nail" things into the side of wooden furniture and snapped them off or bent them. These held up better for such use, though it probably isn't recommendable. All in all, these are a better quality office supply for a reasonable price, but, if your needs are putting notices on soft cork boards, you probably can get by with something cheaper and flimsier.

reviewText:
This is my first HP printer for home, though I've used dozens of different HP laser printer models at work for the last 20 years. The printer itself deserves almost 5 stars, I really love it. It has a few drawbacks, but at this price it's perfect for a home or small office machine.

My 11 year old Brother multi-function finally gave up the ghost, so I'm amazed at how much faster printing, scanning, faxing, and copying are now. I'm especially pleased that this printer doesn't curl the output paper like Brothers printers tend to.

One reviewer mentioned how the document feed tends to pull the paper a little crooked. This seems to be more of a problem with short stacks of paper, and is most likely the result of there being only one pinch roller in the middle of the paper path. It's less of a problem if the sheet guides are as close as possible, but that makes it more difficult to get the paper into the tray. This might be a non-starter for a small business, but I can live with it.

One other thing to watch out with the feeder: as usual with low end printers the feeder is a bit finicky about pulling sheets. It may not pull any or, if you push the originals a little much, it may pull multiple sheets.

This might not be the printer's problem, but scanning to or printing from a USB flash drive seems to be pretty slow. It is easy to use the USB drive, though, and navigating folders is simple. Printing from my PC though the USB input is fast, though.

No problem setting up the WiFi (for use with other devices).

The software package works just fine. The printer console is easy to use, but most if not all of that is available from the printer's touchscreen as well. I now have a problem deciding whether to use my Nuance PowerPDF software or the scanner software from HP. Need more time to make that decision.

Now for the big problem. HP's installer is rubbish. I have a fully updated Win8.1 PC, but HP's installer could run the MSI services. It took a chat session with 3 hours of remote desktop control to fix the problem. I didn't pay full attention to the whole process (took care of paperwork, read, drank iced tea, and whatever) but did notice at one point that the tech disabled regserv, which is rather alarming. I ran a full system check when we were done and everything seems fine, but this is ridiculous. Reminds me of the worst of UNIX makes. Don't know how common this problem is, but 3 hours for one printer is a lot of money no matter how little the techs get paid.

Pros:
1) fast at almost everything
2) paper loads in front and you can see how much paper is left
3) features work as advertised except for document feeder as noted above
4) backlit touchscreen easy to read in any light

Cons:
1) The touchscreen is a little bit non-responsive, but then my fingers don't work well with most touchscreens
2) document feeder misalignment
3) document feeder can grab multiple sheets
4) software installation
5) USB speed
summary: Great personal multi-function printer, but SW install flawed

reviewText:
I used the original 3M Precision Mousing Surface with mechanical mice for years. When I converted to optical devices, I found the 3M products did not work very well. In a lot of cases with an optical mouse, no pad or special surface of any kind is actually needed. My desk, however, has a glass top and an optical mouse will not work at all on it. I've been using a leather mouse pad from Ikea for a long time. As it happens, it works very well with an optical mouse. It has only two drawbacks: (1) it's black, making it hard to tell when it's getting gunked up and needs cleaning, and (2) despite being fairly heavy (it's leather covering a metal disc) it has a tendency to very slowly creep toward the back of my desk.

The 3M Precise Optical Mousing Surface (MP200PS) addresses both of these issues and also seems to allow somewhat more meticulous mouse movement. The mousing surface is very thin and with a textured silver-grey color that will make it easy to tell when it needs cleaning. I actually kind of like the feel of the textured surface on my fingertips.

It has a repositionable adhesive (like a Post-It note) on the underside. 3M's idea is that this allows you to stick it to the outside of your laptop when not in use; in my case, it guarantees that it will not move at all on my glass desktop. The package says the repostionable adhesive is warranted for one year. This adhesive should also mitigate a problem I sometimes had with the original product: a tendency to start curling slightly at one of the corners after many months of use.

As I wrote above, my old leather mouse pad was remarkably effective when used with an optical mouse. My perception is that the 3M Precise Optical Mousing Surface (MP200PS) does make my mouse (an Apple Mighty Mouse) somewhat more responsive to my hand movements. Whether this will translate into battery savings remains to be seen. As it happens, I just put a new set of batteries in this mouse a couple of days ago. I generally get 2-3 months of almost daily use out of a pair of lithium AA's. I will try to update this review the next time I change batteries.

If you want a mousing surface to carry along with your laptop or you need one that will stay put on a glass desktop, the 3M Precise Optical Mousing Surface (MP200PS) is a good choice.
summary: Designed for laptops, also useful on the desktop

I love this pen. I bought both the EF and the F nib versions, because I had read that the EF was closer to the F for the rest of Lamy pens, and I was upgrading from a Studio Fine that have loved as my sole fountain pen and daily writer for five years.

The verdict is that with moderate pressure, the Lamy 2000 EF and Lamy Studio F are about the same, however, the 2000 EF is more sensitive to pressure and gets considerable variation in line width. The Lamy 2000 F, however, is pretty much exactly like the Studio F, and I notice a similar near-absence of line width variation. The F nib is smoother writing, and tolerates different hand angles better, so for daily use and notes, I'm using the F. For letters I've started using the EF, because the line is so wonderful.

Extremely happy with my Lamy pens.

I received the Canon PIXMA PRO-100 Color Professional Inkjet Photo Printer as part of the Amazon Vine review program. I've owned several inkjet printers from Canon, HP, and most recently the Epson WorkForce 545 Wireless All-in-One Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner, Fax, iOS/Tablet/Smartphone/AirPrint Compatible (C11CB88201), but never before had the pleasure of using a 'pro' quality photo printer. First impression, "This thing is HUGE!" The box weighed 54 pounds and the printer filled most of that space. Used to smaller footprints, I had to figure out a space for it. Luckily it's wireless and I could put it anywhere in my house. Eventually I decided on a location and started unboxing it. In the box is all the stuff you need to get started. Cords, ink cartridges, photo paper (a few sheets), software on CD for both PC and Mac users, a sheet of instructions and a CD tray. After you take off all the tape and remove padding per the instructions, you power it up and let it sit for about 2 minutes while things align. Then you put in the ink cartridges (of which there are (8); unwrapping, unscrewing the ink cap, and setting them into the print head, which you will have already installed prior to plugging in the printer. IF your cartridges are not seated properly in the printer, you'll see an orange light on the front of the printer. I saw the orange light, reseated the cartridges and still had the orange light. I ended up checking out Canon's online support and found that it could also be an improperly locked bail on the printer head, which locks down the ink cartridges. It was, and once secured, the orange light went away. Loading paper per the instructions sheet should be easy, but it was confusing to me. There are actually two paper intake slots. One at the very back of the printer, and one a bit forward of that. The forward one is the slot you want, but it took me way too long to figure that one out! After you have things set with ink, paper and only the white (power) light and the blue (Wifi - if using that option) light, then it's time to add the software and drivers via your PC or Mac. Mine installed in approximately 15 minutes on a Windows 7 64-bit PC with plenty of 'oomph' to do the job. Printer was recognized and a toolbar (L shaped) at the bottom of my desktop screen appeared. A launchpad for printing, tweaking and manuals for this device. I printed two test pages and both were quickly produced on Canon Photo Paper Glossy, 8.5 x 11 Inches, 100 Sheets (0775B024), offering vibrant results from my own digital images. No tacky residue or smearing of the ink, certainly beautiful results as expected from this professional inkjet. I also printed from photos taken on my iPad via AirPrint - a fantastic feature - which came out great too! The reason I give it 4 out of 5 stars has more to do with my frustration over the set-up and the size/weight of the printer. I'm not a novice at setting up printers, but the directions on this one while 'simple', would benefit from photos versus diagrams and a bit more information - not requiring the user to go to the Canon site for clarification. The weight and size of this beast may be a necessary evil to get awesome results, but those with limited space will need to 'make a hole and make it wide' for this one. Overall, for printing professional quality prints, brochures, and similar, it's a great choice. Feature-rich with fine detailed print reproduction from digital images, the Canon PIXMA Pro 100 is as promised. I recommend it!
summary: A few struggles with set-up, results are picture perfect

Paper itself is pretty decent.  It's as good as the regular grade copy paper you'd buy at any chain store, although several bucks cheaper.  What I found annoying, and noted by a few others, is that they seem to be subject to pretty rough handling in storage and/or in transit, as upwards of 50-60% of the individual reams seem to wind up having their packing ripped.  Generally, the actual paper inside doesn't get affected much, but you may get some badly wrinkled and/or soiled.

With regards specifics, I have gotten three cartons so far.  One came completely pristine.  Another came with a couple of reams with ripped packing--but no damage to the paper--and another came in fairly deplorable condition, with all but one of the reams with ripped packing (and two reams with some of their contents soiled and/or badly wrinkled.)  Still, given the quality-price combination, I'd get more of this, as long as the price remains competitive enough.

I've been looking for something like this for a long time and was fortunate to have stumbled across this at random. Recently, I did a huge bulk purchase of Post-it notes. Consequently, I use them with reckless abandon. The NoteTower simplifies the process because of the clips. The one piece of advice that I have is don't try to push it around and move it ... even just a few inches ... if the wheels are locked.  Overtime, that ended up straining the weld of the post and bar under the table and it broke.  That was totally my fault.  Make sure the wheels with the locks are towards you and not on the opposite side of the table.  Lock the wheels if you need to, but reach down and unlock the wheels if you need to move the table ... if you remember that, the table should last forever.

My brother has one at his house too, and loves it.

The printer is a little noisy. It does a lot of resetting. It also will not work unless every cartridge has ink, which is ridiculous when only printing in black ink. So if I have plenty of black ink and am printing only in black ink but one of the color cartridges is out, the printer will not operate.

The major issue is the cost of the ink. The average price seems to be almost $50 for the 5-pack combo and $20 for a black cartridge. With tax, the cost to replace the print cartridges is over $70. That is unacceptable.

In these bad economic times, it is hard to justify this expense. I'm looking at other options. If I can get a good deal on another brand and the ink is cheaper, I may be much better off in the long run.

I'm using these labels on a Dymo 450 Turbo on a Mac.

If you were hoping to use these labels to print Paypal shipping, look for the one-part labels instead. Even after a lot of fiddling, you cannot get these labels to print postage correctly (it will print sideways from Paypal, meaning only a portion of the tracking number is printed, the rest is blank) unless you do a clever workaround in Cups and Photoshop. Even then, it prints backwards (the postage prints where it says "return" and "recipient" and the return and recipient prints where it says "postage". So you have to pull all four pieces (even the bit that's meant to be thrown away) off the strip and pieces them back together on the packaging. It looks incredibly unprofessional, and you have to do a bit of resizing in Photoshop as well because the only settings Paypal has for Labelwriter 330 and 330 Turbo, whose labels are 7.5", not 7" like these.

Normally I'd have given these labels an okay rating, but then I found out that Dymo won't even give out the template for this label, or ANY internet postage labels! According to their troubleshooting page, these labels are only compatible Stamps.com or Endicia. I wish they'd printed this on the box or put that in the product description - unfortunately I wasted $16.
summary: Only works with Stamps or Endicia - no template for Dymo.

These key tags are a great bargain and work very well for tagging keys - and other stuff.

I have several dozen keys that are spares or infrequently-used, and until I got these I had been using those "old fashioned" tags that are round paper with a circular aluminum rim.  Those tended to wear out, rip, and fade ... and I had to read through the labels to find the right key at times because they were all one color.

These are a huge improvement because they are much more durable, come in various colors so I can make some attempt at organizing my keys, have holes at each end for hanging better, have a clear plastic cover over the label area to protect the writing, and they look nice.  Their usefulness has inspired me to use them to label a few other items as well, such as a set of pouches I use for sorting out some infrequently used items but were a nuisance because I couldn't tell what size item was in each pouch without opening it.  Now I have a solution for that too.

These would have been *perfect* if they had provided some way to show the label on both sides, and if the metal keyrings had been just a tiny bit thicker/stronger.  But for the price I am not complaining.

reviewText: I've always trusted the Swingline name for quality office products, and this new 2-hole punch lives up to its reputation.  The handsome design is made of solid metal with a comfortable padded handle cover, as well as a rubber base/cover to protect work surface and hold the punch waste.  A convenient adjustable paper guide allows for accurate center punch alignment of standard size widths from 4" to 12" wide papers, with a lock mechanism.  However, the guide has a U.S. Standard ruler that can be adjusted for other measurements up to 13", or it can be easily removed to accommodate larger widths by hand if needed.  In addition, the handle can be locked down for easy storage, but be careful not to push it in too far or it may be a little difficult to retract.  The holes are 1/4", it can punch up to 28 sheets at a time, and it has a limited lifetime warranty (assuming normal usage).
I've had it for quite some time and it's holding up perfectly.

I have been a businessman running my office for 43 years.  I have picked up printers of all kinds...Panasonic, H-P, Cannon, Epson from off my desk and walked them out to the dumpster and tossed them.  I got a Samsung printer about 4 years ago.  It worked.  Repeatedly.  Always.  Now, I am not the techie type to have my stuff operate wirelessly, so this review is not for you if you want that.  But, if you are old-fashioned and use a wire from computer to printer, this thing won't steer you wrong.  Only item to note...when the printer cartridge is out of ink...it all stops.  Right now.  So, I keep plenty on hand so I always have a spare.  Also, I empty the little toner dust collector.  They want you to buy a new one but I shake it out and it works just fine.  To give you an idea.  I moved offices recently and hired 2 people.  I got them each one of these printers.  Everything hums along just fine.  Sure, the toner costs 75 bucks a pop, but by now, if I can't afford it, I should close up shop.  Oh, I have tried the off brand toner cartridges...it is a bit spotty.  Sometimes they don't work and into the dumpster they go.  I am too poor to buy cheap.  I will skip lunch once or twice a week to make sure I have Samsung Toner Cartridges.  So far, in 4 years, they have worked and worked.  My personal one is an older model, but they all use the same toner cartridge.  There you go...hope this helps.

It should have been easy to put together as others had mentioned.  Everything was labeled correctly.  The package was easy to open and we love the Two Day Amazon Prime Delivery.  However, although the Back Board #3 and the bottom shelf illustrated holes in the sides for the screws, they were covered by the black material that surrounds the board.  I was prepared to make some changes myself since I don't like to return items.  After thinking about the problem for awhile, I decided to try to tap the board by using a small drill bit.  I aligned the board prior to drilling through the open hole in the frame.  I got lucky!  The drill bit punctured the black covering on one of the two places I tried.  I finally realized the white plastic screws on the top of the shelf board are in the area where the long screws go through the metal frame and line up at this point.  Once I broke through, I did the remaining seven holes in the same way and used the provided Allen wrench to tighten the screws..

Although some reviewers thought the keyboard drawer should have slid out more, the keyboard we have just does just make it okay.  I put the monitor and mouse on the top.  The keyboard is on the slide out tray.  By the way, these screw holes were clearly visible for this part.  Our old, large desktop computer is on the floor next to this compact desk.  If it were put on the shelf our desktop computer would hang over because it is two inches larger than the shelf plus the connecting cables that stick out. The shelf is about 15" which may be given in the description with the dimensions for this desk.  Our printer fits perfectly on the bottom shelf.  Small computer desks are hard to find so this met our needs.
summary: It's Easy to Put Together if !

I bought this printer for a couple of specific reasons - to do double-sided colour printing on plain paper and to print presentation certificates.  I already had a B&W laser printer.  I read the reviews, many negative, but bought anyway, reasoning that complainers always complain but satisfied customers stay silent.

This is a quality printer at a bargain price.  It does everything I want it to and does it very well.  B&W printing is a little heavy (much heavier than my HP) but looks good.  Color printing is excellent; not as good, of course, as an inkjet photo printer, but good all the same.  Default color is somewhat dark but easily fixed with a quick adjustment of the color histogram in the options settings.  I have printed photos on light card to send to friends - they come out nicely.  The brochures I print (double-sided color) are terrific. Color is a matt finish, not the part-glossy look of many color lasers, and is harder to pick as color laser output.

Duplexing works well - no issues.  Envelope printing is good.  Paper feed is straight - I print on pre-printed certificates and the alignment is perfect (better than my HP).  Initial set-up took 20 minutes and was easy.  Noise level is comparable with other B&W lasers.

Niggles? Hardly any. It's comparatively slow to warm up from standby (but acceptable). Occasionally a single sheet of 80gsm in the multi-purpose try fails to pick up and registers a jam.  Putting half a dozen sheets in prevents this. It's heavy and takes up a fair bit of desk space.

Summary: For home use, small office or a networked business this is an excellent printer. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
I've been purchasing many printers for nearly two decades and because we do so much printing, we go through a lot of printers and have went through the negatives such as expensive ink, paper getting stuck and no easy way of removing it, getting stuck and ruining the spools or certain attachments breaking off.  And needless to say, I've come to the point where I know what kind of printer to buy and what I'm willing to spend on one.

And recently through Amazon Vine I was able to test out the Epson Stylus NX420 Color Ink Jet All-In-One.  For one, Epson has been a wonderful brand when it comes to printers, scanners, etc.  In the two decades of using Epson printers, I've come upon a few that have caused me some gray hairs mainly due to the paper carriage and paper getting stuck.  But I've gone through the motions of testing this printer out and I have to say, for its price at under $70, this is a very good printer for the budget-conscious person.

A.  Installation

Installation was easy.  After removing the plastic and installing the ink cartridges which was easy, just plug it in to your electrical outlet and because it is a wireless printer, just enter your wi-fi security code and install the software on your computer (test on a Mac and PC) and no problems.  Printing right off the bat. (Note: The printer also comes with a USB plug-in).

B.  Copying

The first step was copying a few documents and printing it out.  Sure enough, the copy and print using the panel controls was easy and straightforward.  Press copy and how many pages and that's it.

C.  Scanner

The scanner resolution is 5760x1440 dpi and scanner resolution is 2400 dpi.  I do a lot of scanning especially on my Epson Perfection scanner but this time I tried scanning everything from DVD and Blu-ray to CD inserts and seeing how good the quality is and for the most part, I was impressed and I liked the amount of space given for scanning.  It's not small and also, easy to use.

D.  Printer

This printer supposedly prints B/W pages at 35 ppm and color at 15 ppm.  I was surprised by how quick it took to print.  No long warmup, it just started printing after a few second of pressing print and I like that.

E.  Paper Carriage

This is a top loading printing device.  I am now a big proponent for flat-laying printing devices as top-loading printers have caused me nothing but grief in the past.  I will say that I like how Epson has put a plastic guard right on the top and made the stand behind the paper easy to use and not detachable.  I like how the paper holder on the front comes out, is collapsible and easy to put back up again.  There is no fail-safe in the back to pull out the paper if your printer eats up your paper and for me, it's important to have that capability.

And like all printers, you get bundled software and for its price at under $70, that's pretty good.

But as I mentioned the positives, what are the negatives?

- One thing I noticed, especially with my parents is they love the ability to take their flash card from their camera, put it into a slot in the printer and print from that.  This is not the printer that can do that and you usually have to pay around near a $100 for that capability.
-  Cost of ink.  Truthfully, ink is expensive no matter what printer you buy.  Fortunately, Epson and HP are the most reasonable (sorry Lexmark, you're prices and the amount of ink in those cartridges are not reasonable) and easy to find at stores.  It is true that you can buy each cartridge at around $8.99 but in this case, you have four cartridges (one black, three color). Black goes for $15.99 while color goes around $30+.  This is where HP tends to rival Epson and that's the pricing of the color ink.  But if you don't use your printer for color printing and are mostly focused on black and white printing, then at $15.99, that's usually the average ($13-$18).
- No rear paper remover if your papers get garbled and stuck.  No easy way to pull it off.  Granted, I have not had that experience with this printer but having had many printers damaged because of bad paper, its useful to have that capability to go from the back and pull it out.  You can't do that with this printer.

JUDGMENT CALL:

Compared to other printers around $39-$69, I have to admit that you get a lot for your money with the Epson Stylus NX420.  Printing is very good, speed is very good, ease of use is very good but there are some other things that people may need (especially the flash card capability or even capability to print on photos via a special carriage) which requires for the user to spend about $40-$50 for the next models up.

But this printer is for those who don't need all the bells and whistles.  Students that just need a printer that can scan, copy and print especially if you are just using it for black and white printing and occasional color and need that wi-fi capability.  So, for its price and how it performed during my tests, it's a very good all-in-one printer for its price point.  Definitely recommended!
summary: For its price, the bells and whistles it does come with and the brand behind the printer, makes this printer a solid buy!!!

We have never had to replace a blade, but we do not do a heavy volume of paper cutting.  If you take care of these trimmers they will last a long time.
I had used RotaTrim paper trimmers for photographs in college, and was impressed, so when we needed a quality paper trimmer, these were my first choice.  They are pricey, but worth the money. (I had tried an inexpensive trimmer which had never cut really square, and did not last long)
My one little gripe is with the stick on rubber feet that RotaTrim uses on the bottom, we had one of the feet come off (granted it took years for it to come off)  I recently replaced all the the stick on rubber feet with screw on rubber feet, they seem much better. See Amazon link for the rubber feet I used: (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B079Z7Z73Z/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&th=1)  I attached the feet using #6 - 1/2" screws.  It is a good idea to occasionally check that the rail attachment screws are tight, on the underside of the trimmer, (to left of the rubber foot in the attached photo)

I just replaced my larger HP 7410 all-in-one officejet printer with this one because the 7410's printer head was no longer printing (about 3 years old), most likely due to no preventative maintenance on my part.
I decided on the smaller printer because my family just does not print much anymore.  Even our high school junior simply prints out his essays/assignments on the school printers when needed.

The setup is very easy.  The electrical cord has no no AC/DC converter box on it anymore, which is nice.  You just plug it in and set up the wireless connection with your wifi.  You can connect wire connect but will need to have your own cable since one is not provided.

I found that it prints much faster than my 7410 or even the HP officejet pro 6830, which is the larger version of this 3830.
In lieu of a paper tray, this printer has slot that you insert the paper at the back of the printer.  You can see the paper sticking up in the back so you know when you are low on paper.
Here are its dimensions:
16 inches wide by 10 inches deep by 8 inches high.

It comes with a software installation CD but it is much easier to just get it online at http://support.hp.com/us-en/drivers.  You can also use the touch screen on the printer to check for printer updates by going to the Setup screen.

This printer only uses 2 print cartridges: one black and one for color, instead of the typical 4 cartridges (1 black, 3 color).

To summarize, this is a great printer for light duty home and/or home office or even for a HS or college student.  The small footprint, easy setup, and 2 ink cartridges are big plusses.
summary: Great for Home or Light Duty Office Printing

Lots of reviewers have listed the specs for this phone set, so I'll simply give you my experience as a user. My favorite thing about this phone is the speaker volume on the handset - I can hear even faint callers speaking. The phone is lightweight, so after the initial surprise at how light it is, I found no problems with it- it is solidly built.  It comes with an instruction book, but if you're familiar with digital handsets, you'll already know much of it. It's easy to add to the phone book, and the menu is logical for the most part.  The answering machine's sound replay quality is good and it's easy to select delete, save, skip, etc., from either the base unit or the handsets.  The range seems pretty good - I can take it outside front and back yards and still hear everything clearly.

What I really don't like is how it rings. The base unit will ring first, and then as it begins a second ring, one hand unit starts to ring. The second unit doesn't ring until the base is on its third ring! I haven't found any sort of way to adjust this delay. It may be related to the distance from the base, I don't know. Also, the ring on the hand units is not all that loud at max volume.

Overall, I rate it a 4, mainly because of the weird ringing behavior. Otherwise, I like the phone and it's as good as the Panasonic that it's replacing - for a lot less cost.

Update: I've gotten used to the weird ringing and it doesn't bother me any more. One thing I missed - you can't use the base unit as a speakerphone, it is strictly for charging and recording/listening to messages. However the handsets' speaker phone sound is quite good.

UPDATE; Over the past six months the handsets became erratic, sometimes holding a charge for a while, other times dying after only a few minutes even though they were fully charged.  I gave up on them and ordered a new phone set by Panasonic. I've had good luck with them as well as AT&T phones which lasted many years.  Two years is not acceptable as far as I am concerned.
summary: Good sound, overall nice phone- Update: died in 2 years

This is not your old style of heavy, block style office printer, yet it can hold up to a busy office workload like the bigger models. A stapler only has to do 3 things well, in my opinion:

1. Drive staples straight, even through thick stacks of paper
2. Not require too much effort to squeeze
3. Be easy to reload

This thing actually excels at all 3.  I laugh writing this about something as basic as a stapler,
but I have had to use staplers that misfire, are a chore to pull open to reload, or
mangle 1 staple for every one they punch successfully.

This stapler has a built-in spring-loaded "drive", so a relatively light squeeze, and it
"fires" a staple with a lot of power.  I could put it through 1/4" of paper with just
a gentle squeeze.

It reloads on the bottom by just easily sliding open a door.  The only slight negative
I noticed was that if the row of staples that you load into it are broken apart
into sections, it will occasionally fire more than one and fail, so it's best to
put a single neat row of staples into the chamber.

Okay. I'm a fan of Post-it items. I use the original (old-school?) yellow, square Post-it notes regularly. I have the page/tab/flag dividers. I've even used the huge flip-chart Post-it notes.

These, however, serve zero purpose for me.

Maybe if I were in college? No. Because I'd just highlight and write directly in my textbook. And most of my notes would be on the computer (paper stickies don't work so well there).

Maybe if I were a CEO? No. Again, I'd use a computer. Or have an administrative assistant to organize for me.

Wait! I cook often. What about for my recipe books? Again, no. I scan the recipes I like and put them in a tabbed and labeled binder. And write directly on the pages.

The idea behind these is a good one, I suppose; it just was not implemented well. While I still have zero idea when and how I would use these Post-it note tabs, the fact that I can only use them vertically is kind of annoying. What if I want to tab the top or bottom of something? The lines to write on would be going up and down. Not at all helpful.
summary: I'm Rather Organized But Have Zero Use For These

I have used the Pilot Precise V7 RT Ink refills for a long time and they are outstanding. The ink does not blot often and runs smoothly across the page. The ink is a solid dark color and stays dark after drying almost instantly. The ink does not bleed through most paper, which is really great because it still has a great dark color. I have yet to have a problem when writing with these pens for any purpose.

I have used the ink for multiple purposes: writing letters, papers, check lists, shopping lists, writing labels.

Throughout all of my experience I have only found one minor issue-- the ink runs out quickly. If you can snatch these refills for a good price then how quickly they run out should not be an issue. In my experience I have found that these refills run out about twice as fast as Pilot G2.

Overall I highly recommend these refills to all pen users.
summary: Smooth and even flow, but runs out quickly

reviewText:
Many people get frustrated with how long the ink will last with their printers.  It is important to note that this is an issue with all printers and all ink.  The name brand is always better than a recycled cartridge as well.  I feel very lucky for my printer requires merely a cartridge for black, color and one for photo printing if need be.  I only use the black and color and find with the black ink the estimated 220 page yield is pretty accurate.  I don't do major project priniting like graphics or anything.

Many of my friends have printers that require black and a cartridge for each individual color for a total of about 6 cartridges before it will even print.  How much more expensive that would be.  And they have the same problem with how long the ink lasts.  I tried recycled cartridges for awhile for they are a little cheaper but they would always clog after a while and I would then have to use the clean process thru the printer which uses much ink.  I got at least a 30% lesser page yield with these recycled ones and also had the added frustration.  To get full deep clarity of color in the printing was rare.  But when I use the name brand HP I never have the cartridges clog, the printings are always full with no fading and I can check the ink level on my computer.  I just accept the page yield I get from them, purchase them at Amazon where I get great prices and I can always rely on great printing.  Again sadly, the page yield is a problem with all brand printers.  And the price I paid here for the 2 black cartridges was unbelievable.  I understand the frustration but say this is the best quality and longest yielding ink you will get for an HP printer.  Highly recommend.

The two-pen set of "Bic For Her Fashion Ball Pens" are fine writing instruments. They start writing on contact, without smudging (important for someone left handed) and are comfortable to hold, with rubberized padding on the lower portion of the pens.  The "for her" fashion marketing, I suspect, might not appeal to all, given the dated cliche of the design.  The inks are pink and lavender, respectively, with correspondingly colored plastic parts, both decorated with fleur-de-lis like graphics. Beyond one's view of fashion, it may also be limiting if one doesn't wish to write or sign professional documents with those colors.
summary: Nice writing pens; but for her?

I wanted a tiny adjustable high-quality pocket sharpener for those times when I'm not carrying my shoulder bag with a full complement of fountain pens, Blackwings, various erasers, Strathmores, and KUM two-stage long-point sharpener.

This little brass work of art fills that role.

It sharpens, as advertised, to three different sharpness levels, and it makes a smooth symmetrical cut at each setting with a well-formed point. I use setting 1 when I need just enough of a point to write legibly and setting 3 when I need fine detail in a drawing. The leather case is well made and protects the blade of the sharpener while keeping one's pocket clean. It seemed expensive, but now that I've lived with it for a while, I think of it more in the nature of an heirloom-quality objet d'art than an overpriced gadget.

Kinda disappointed in the heat output of this, but then, I guess you can only get so much out of 90 watts.  It is what it says it is, though, and it doesn't have the problems of many competitors I read the reviews of.  Namely, that they smell like burning rubber when turned on and they don't have an on/off switch.  This one has no strange smells coming out of it and not only is there an on/off switch on the front but it turns off automatically after 8 hours, which is perfect.

I got it mainly for the office, which is never warm enough (and is actually worse in the summer, when the building blasts AC) and I didn't think they'd approve of a 300+ watt space heater, which, aside from burning electricity, tends to raise fears of burning the building down.

I like the textured surface and the way the footrest angles.  The ability to warm the tops of your feat by putting them underneath seems a bit of a stretch though because it's just a pad that radiates heat -- you aren't getting much heat without putting your feet on top of it.

So, my guess is you'll probably wish it was warmer, but there's no apparent drawbacks to it.  Incidentally, the thermostat makes an audible "bloop" sound when it goes off and on, which is weird, but whatevas.
summary: Better than the alternatives, I guess?

The first time I bought liquid highlighters I was in college and was afraid to spend my money on them, but took a chance. I LOVED them! They were uni-Blazers by EF and, unfortunately, they aren't made any more (not that I can find anyway). I bought them in 1994 and still use them now in 2010! The ink never dried out. Admittedly, I didn't use them consistently all those years, but I did use them quite a bit when I did. The point is--just because it's a liquid highlighter doesn't mean it has to dry out or run out quickly! ... unlike these Sharpie Accents. I bought this pack because I really liked the other liquid ones and thought these looked nice. Unfortunately, I've been using the yellow one for only two weeks and the ink is half gone!! I thought perhaps the other reviewers were leaving the caps off while they read, but no, I faithfully put the cap back on immediately each time.

The other thing I really, really dislike about these is that when I use an index card to keep my underlining straight and then move the index card down a line it smears the ink! No other highlighters I've ever used have done this. This doesn't dry as fast as others do. It seems these put too much ink on the page, even thought they don't bleed through much--they do a little. I tried the other colors and they all behaved the same way.

Also, the cap is really hard to get on and off. There is a little plastic area in the cap that uses a spring to create a seal on the top of the marker. I'm guessing it's to keep it from drying out. But it makes it hard to get on and off, which makes it quite annoying to put the cap back on every time you use it.

These highlighters are very bright. You probably won't overlook a highlighted portion of text on a page. Sometimes, I feel it is too bright, but that's just a personal preference. If you like a very bright marker and don't mind it running out really quickly, these might be ok for you. They do look nice and don't feel too bad in the hand--I'm pretty picky that way.

So, I'm going to try another brand and give these to my daughter to play with till they finish running out.

reviewText: For the past 15 years, I've purchased HP printers and have been very happy with the quality of their products- until now. I purchased this printer six months ago, and have been disappointed with its performance and features. I use this printer in my home office, and find that it is a bit noisy.  If I want to print something I make sure I'm not on the phone, or in a meeting. Print jobs often get "stuck" and will not process until you restart the printer- a time consuming event.  In addition, the paper feed often gets jammed.  The envelope printing feature is a disaster.  The envelopes usually get stuck, or they will print with ink smudges.  I also found their scanning feature lacking.  If you scan a document, it will scan a regular sized paper into a huge file.  Needless to say, I wouldn't recommend this printer for a home office.
I'm learning calligraphy and these are the Best pens I've ever bought !  I'm Getting ready to reorder even  though after much use, the first pen is still going strong!
Sticks well. Reasonable price.

(Please see updates at the end of this review)

I know this machine is feature rich, and the print quality is excellent, but I am quite disappointed with the software.  Twice the installer hung forever and required a system restart in Mac OS X (current version), and I finally ignored the CD and installed through CUPS (localhost:631).  This was annoying enough, but it also selectively fails to print, with no indication that anything is wrong other than a job forever stuck in "waiting to complete" state.  I have two other printers that work fine, so this is not a newbie issue, although it does entail the somewhat greater complexity of a printer-sharing setup and may be more reliable on a direct USB connection to the host machine.

When it works, it does so smoothly and quickly, and the envelope handling (from Endicia) is noticeably better than my trusty Epson.  I have not tried the photo-quality printing for which this unit is famous, so this is not a comprehensive review... just a comment on the Mac integration.  I'm fairly loyal to Canon as I love their cameras, but the bloatware that ships with this printer is both inscrutable and fragile in the OSX environment.

UPDATE 1:  Since my initial writing of this review, it has died completely:  it is convinced that the cyan ink tank is not recognized, even though it is FULL.  This prevents any operation of the printer, and cannot be bypassed with re-inserting the cartridge, resetting, power cycling, or anything else.

UPDATE 2 (about 2 weeks later):  I have to credit Canon's tech support for responding well... they quickly shipped a replacement Cyan ink tank, which fixed the problem.  Stopping and restarting the printer in CUPS released the hung jobs, and it is now working quickly and smoothly.

UPDATE 3:  (a few months later) OK, final word on this.  I hate it.  When it works, it is fast and produces beautiful output.  But it's flaky, and even running out of paper is a traumatic experience that requires power-cycling, fiddling, stopping and starting the printer in CUPS, and various incantations (not all polite).  I would absolutely not get another of these, even free.

reviewText:
The twelve mini crates arrived in a sturdy box. When I opened the box the crates were neatly and tightly stacked in the box and showed no damage from their shipping. We have purchased crates, practically identical to these, in the past from various retailers. The material of these new ones seemed slightly less thick than our older ones. I compared their weight and the new ones are about 3/4 of an ounce lighter than the older ones. Three of the twelve have minor  trivial  "melted" plastic defects to small areas of the crates. None of the defects are such that they impair the utility of the crates, but will call for some attention when stacking or coupling them with other crates.
February 2016: In packing for an upcoming move I tried something that others might find useful. I took four of these Sterilite Mini Crates and, using their "clipping" projections, assembled then into a square. I then tried to fit the square of 4 crates into a medium size "Smart Move" Banker's Box. With a bit of care they fit in with a snug fit. A second set of 4 fit on top to form a second layer. I see this as a near-perfect way to store assorted small objects, either for moving or (in Military lingo) "Non-Temporary Storage."
summary: Fit Well in a Medium Size Banker's Box

We thought our HP Photosmart printer ink was the cause of the ink smearing when wet, but were pleasantly surprised when that problem went away with this paper.  This is good high quality paper.  The only issue I have is that the paper in some of the reams is slightly bent in the corners, a result of carelessness during handling and delivery of the paper.

This is my first experience with scanning negatives and slides, so my review will be from the point of view of a beginner.

I found the instructions to be relatively easy to use once I understood what was going on, there is a bit of a learning curve involved, so plan to do this when you have the time and the patience to start off right.

I had boxes of negatives of images that were damaged in a basement flood, so I was thrilled to find out that something like this exists and for a reasonable price compared to paying someone else to do it for me. The reason being that I would have basically had to go through and look at each image on each negative, try to decide which one to have converted and take the risk of paying to convert a bunch of crappy pics just trying to find one good one.

I think the resulting images are more than acceptable and I like having control. Don't expect to just feed your film into this thing like a ticket muncher at a video arcade, it's a bit slower than that. But you get to preserve your old photos and slides and have the bonus of having them in digital form now so it's quick and easy to share them, have prints made or create slideshows. I was sent a sample unit to use and tell people what I think, good or bad.
summary: Box of old slides and negatives now neatly stored in digital format :)

Smooth nib, beautiful pen.  Fine is a fairly fat fine, IMO (fatter line than Pilot Metropolitan medium, about the same as a Lamy Al-Star fine, maybe a little fatter).  The big problem with this pen is that the cap is not air tight, so your ink will dry out more quickly than it should - it was noticeable for me (I live in a low-humidity area).  So unless you plan to use up all the ink in basically a single use, or are in a place so humid that the ink won't evaporate, you may want to choose another pen.  (I tried to seal the pen cap, and found that it can't be done with the clip still on the cap, so I basically destroyed the cap: removed the clip, filled the place where it was with epoxy, sanded down the epoxy and cap, and painted it.  It looks ugly compared to how it looked before, but it's now air-tight and should hold ink without drying out - still need to test that - will post back if it didn't work, but I expect it will, since it's now air-tight.)
summary: Smooth nib, good-looking, but cap is not air-tight

reviewText: I absolutely LOVE Noodlers Polar inks.  They are the best inks in my Lamy pens.  They make my pens seem to glide across the paper.  I have the Polar Black, Polar Brown, Polar Blue and Polar Green, and they all perform just as well.  I have left my pen by mistake in the car overnight in below-freezing temps, and when I brought it in the next day it didn't even skip the first stroke!  I have never had any of the Polar inks feather on me, even with cheap paper.  I'm sorry the other reviewer had a bad experience- I've never had anything but crisp lines.  The ink tends to spread out over the top of the nib a little, but this doesn't bother me at all.  I have never had ink in the cap of the pen, so its not leaking, just showing up on the nib. In one pen, I had Noodlers 'Heart of Darkness', and I can't explain why, but it did not feel as smooth on the paper as the Polar Black does.  It's also 'bullet-proof'- I had fun trying to bleach it off the paper, and you can't!  Love this ink!
Great

reviewText: Great markers! Expo provides rich and consistent supply of ink.
We have bought over 100 of these chairs so far, and love them!

First the good: these pens perform very well, and have a smooth, easy flowing ink that dries almost instantly and therefore does not smear.

However, I bought this set because I like the other Staedtler Triplus fineliners I have, but needed some paler colors. Looking at the cap colors in the picture, I thought these would be perfect. However, only 3 of the pens (orange, pink and green) are actually a light hue. I did not receive the turquoise pen shown, but rather a delft blue, not a pastel blue. The light lavender color pen actually has ink about the shade of a purple African Violet. I also got a medium to dark gray pen, again not a pastel color. I took away a star because of what I feel is a misrepresentation of the colors included with this set.

It escapes me as to why Staedtler does not label their pens with a color name, or at the least a number, so that if you want to order additional sets you can determine if the colors are duplicates of what you already have. It seems like a simple thing to do. Also, most of the cap colors are not a good match AT ALL with the color of the ink that will flow from the pen. This means that you absolutely must make yourself a sample color chart and label the pens yourself so you can consistently choose the correct pen for the color you want.

I have 3 sets of the Staedtler Triplus fineliners, (set of 20, the pastel set and the Nature set) and these comments apply to all of them. All have very smooth flowing ink and perform well, but it is a challenge to find the colors you want if you don't create a labeling system and sample color chart.
summary: Colors are NOT all pastel colors.

After some horrible experiences with non OEM (compatible ink catridges) in my Canon printers, I read some pretty good reviews on LD ink cartridges and decided to take a chance. I have 2 Canon printers and started off, for over a year,  using LD cartridges in my 5 cartridge inkjet with no problems. I had swore never to use anything but Canon OEM in my 2nd printer, an 8 cartridge Canon Pro 9000 Mark 2 photo printer, but my results were so good I started using them and I'm not sorry! Being an amature photographer I print a ton of photos I'm quite particular about color redition. I see absolutely no difference between the Canon OEM cartridges and LD. I've had no issues with mechanical quality either (i.e., leaking cartridges, bad chips), 2 years running now. At over half the price of Canon OEM cartridges I can actually afford to use my printer for what it was intended for.
summary: Using for 2 years and still very pleased

No programming necessary. You can even copy recipes & pictures out of books. That was an important quality of the old days, but now you just search the internet if you want to know how to cook it.

First of all, let me say that the pen itself is very nice. I'm just testing the waters of calligraphy and fine writing and this seems like the perfect match.

What I'm not happy about is that I did not get what was promised and shown. The photo for the product shows a somewhat sturdy plastic case, with a snap in slot for the cleaning film and a decent quality converter/cleaner. The case looks like it might be something you'd want to keep, maybe.

My pen came in a very cheap, flimsy clear plastic container. Definitely throwaway packaging. It does not have the converter/cleaner as described and shown. Instead it has a large, cheap plastic eye dropper thing that is only good for cleaning, if that. Picture attached of what I got. Not at all what's shown in the product photo - at least at the time of this writing.

All in all, I'm happy with the pen. I'll probably get a regular converter for it anyway, and probably wouldn't have used the nicer plastic case. But if you promise one thing and show pictures of it, don't deliver something else.

Epson makes superb computer printers, and the Epson  Expression ET-2500 EchoTank is not an exception.  The only problem in the past (for me)has been in ink supplies, and the cost per page of photo prints.

Previous Epson printers were priced lower than this one.  Epsom could do that because they profited from expensive ink cartridge sales.  But this printer comes with two years of ink supplies - expensive cartridges not needed.  (note that  the ink supplied, with the printer, is equivalent to 20 cartridges, or 5 complete sets.)  Just  squirt ink into the reservoir containers.  Epson gets their rightful profits up front, and also makes printing more affordable  .In fact, when initial supplies are used up, users can use any brand of inks of the same quality.  And sticking with Epson inks should also be very affordable.  Users will have a choice.

You should also know that Epson has built-in this feature into a whole line of new printers.  While this one is probably ideal for most consumer users, you may have special needs and prefer one of the others.  .

I think this is the fastest printer I've ever owned, and the image quality is the best. The only problem that I have found so far is that the printer won't t print edge to edge on 4"X6" photo paper, and these unwanted boarders are not the same on all sides.  Epson will probably fix this when they update the app, but I don't know this for sure.

This is the MOST WONDERFUL pen ever! I am a bit of a pen-o-file meaning I like pens all kinds but have decerning tastes in what I am looking for.
This pen is not girlie or pretty but is not ugly either...it has click button depress to extend writting tip. It has a roller ball. It is fine tipped but not scratchy when writting. It has virtually no drag on note paper and is pretty smudge proof( wrote and colored in a circle let dry 10 minutes then wet finger four times over both, paper was wet but ink remained as laid down no change/smudge/or running) wish came in blue have not seen this but personal preference.
The case has a pocket/page clip and a rubber like grip (alergic to latex but no problems). It is very comfortable to hold. I like heavier pens but this is far and away lite in weight BUT I still love it since it is so balanced it is close to effortless to write with, so well made it writes smoothly with litte to no preasure. It just glides on and keeps on going. If I take care not to lean my wrist on what I am writing on, I can write longer than any other pen before my carpal tunnel gets annoyed. AMAZINGLY long time and my case was surgery recommended(but success rate was to much of risk so go with brace/ immobilization therapy) Is it Smooth as butter? No in essence but it is smooth as in no paper drag no scratch proper balance smooth if you know the difference I am trying to explain. Oh and I usually like a .07 width but this is .05 or less(does not say) and I still LOVE IT!  I know I cant explain more why that is it just is! Get one and try it before you go for the 12 set to be sure it fits you. Afterall we all have different hand size writting style and likes right!

reviewText:
I bought these with my boyfriend to use in our classrooms. He needed to make ID badges for journalism and I needed lanyards to hold jeweler's loupes for our Private Eye unit. The 100 pack was perfect for our combined classes so we were happy when they arrived. Thats when I noticed he only negative thing tha  I can say about them.  When we first opened up the packaging there was a very strong plastic-like smell that was rather unpleasant. Thankfully, we had enough time before we needed to use them and so we were able to air them out, which worked well enough to get rid of the scent.

The lanyard is made up of a strong black cord with a metal hook that swivels at the end. Even after a year, the hooks and lanyards are still in great shape, in spite of consistent use by elementary and middle school students. The badges easily attached to the hook. The swivel gave it some flexibility and was also allowed for easy use of the jewelers loupe as students moved them around.

In order to store them, if not doing so separately, I just pile them up into bunches of about ten and use the last one to tie a loose not around them. This seems to work well enough in keeping them from tangling up and is easy to undo.
summary: Works great, but a bit smelly right out of the packaging

reviewText: I have been refilling these cartridges for many years, probably saved $7,000 > $8,000 and refilled cartridges hundred of times for my small business, and you can too. DO NOT REMOVE CARTRIDGES FROM YOUR PRINTER. REPEAT: DO NOT REMOVE CARTRIDGES. Removing the cartridges to refill eventually causes cartridge failure as there is a counter in the printer program that eventually blocks the cartridge continued use. By filling as follows, the program never "knows" the cartridge is being reused: There is a hole on the top of each cartridge. Buy a syringe and needle. Draw ink into the syringe and insert the needle through the top hole WHILE THE CARTRIDGES CONTINUES TO BE IN PLACE. DO NOT PRESS ON OR DISTURB THE CARTRIDGES just easily and delicately find the hole (a little more than midway up the cartridge top, keep gently probing with the sharp syringe needle until you hit the hole through the vinyl sticker over it) and insert the needle. Slowly add ink into cartridge. It helps if you slowly move the needle up and down as it is in a sponge inside the cartridge, and you want to soak as much of the ink holding sponge as possible. When full, if you are pressing the syringe slowly, a little ink will bubble out the top by the needle. Remove the needle/syringe, dab the ink up with a paper towel and GENTLY apply a piece of Scotch tape over the hole. You can use the same syringe for each color, but you must rinse it under running water until it is clear before drawing the next color into it. I use four different syringes, one for each color, so that I clean them all at one time at the sink. If you read this and continue to buy cartridges, something is wrong with you because this is so easy and saves so much money.
