This handset, and the KX-TGA930T, are as far as I know, the only two handsets that work with the KX-TH1212B Panasonic Link-to-Cell Expandable Bluetooth-Enabled DECT 6.0 Phone System. This handset is notably (but not significantly) heavier and feels larger than the KX-TGA930T. The KX-TGA930T are the exact same handsets that come with the KX-TH1212B.

The buttons are all in the same place, so the phone operates exactly the same as the KX-TGA930T. I have not tried dunking it in water or hurling it at the walls, but my wife does take it outside/gardening/etc. We got one of these for that purpose, and it lives on the kitchen counter when it isn't traveling outside.

I have noticed no sound or volume difference compared to the KX-TGA930T. The Red circle and metal-grid graphic (just for looks, it's smooth to the touch) look nice to me but I do prefer the original KX-TGA930T since it is slightly lighter. They will not fit in each other's charging cradles so that helps ensure that the Kitchen phone generally remains in the Kitchen at least!

It pairs without any issue with the KX-TH1212B and stays that way, no issue with dropped calls or disconnected handsets. Range does not seem any different between the two handset models.

A big Pro for me is the batteries are rechargeable AAA's, 2 per handset. You'll never have to buy an expensive proprietary battery. And, when you do replace the AAA's it comes with, you can use your choice of higher mAh ones like Eneloop or Duracell.
summary: Works as expected, but I haven't torture tested it...

reviewText:
Bought to replace a cross-cut shredder purchased several years ago.
What I learned.
Micro-cut shred is better than cross-cut
Shredder is quieter than old unit.
This shredder's rated page shred capacity is less than my old unit by 4 pages, but I learned with the old unit not to believe that because it would frequently stop if the max number of pages was fed. I rarely feed more than 8 pages at a time and this unit works fine. I may try the max number at some point, but for my volume, it won't make a big difference.
Update - after almost a year, the shredder is still working great. My wife just ran a couple bankers boxes of old tax and personal documents through it and other than having to take a couple 45 minute breaks due to the overheat circuit working, it worked very well.

I have two VoIP lines at home. I've had a Panasonic phone with 4 handsets, and a clumsy ugly uncomfortable GE phone with 2 handsets. Both were seriously damaged by the dog, so it was time for an upgrade. Replacement Panasonic handsets are $70, and besides, I wanted more than 4 handsets which was more than Panasonic model supported. So, I went with this Uniden model.

First, the good. The phones are comfortable to hold, very good voice quality, and long range. My adapter is in the garage, and I have no problems on the second floor.

Somebody complained about inability to add 1 for redial or storing from Caller-ID. But, as was explained here, pressing * adds 1 in front of the number. Weird, but it works. One time, I tried to add an international number (that came across on Caller ID, but without any 011 prefix) - and I couldn't. But at least, it adds `1'

One unique benefit if you have two sets. You can set *all* 6 handsets to *both* bases and easily switch between them. So, in the end you get a two-line phone system.

Other good things (but no better than old Panasonic): ability to copy address book, comfortable keypad, bright LCD screen, blinking VM light from answering machine or service provider.

Now the annoying part. Most of those have been described by others. One that I will miss from Panasonic - CallerID voice feature. The phone was "reading" out loud Caller ID name between the rings, so I knew when to ignore kids' friends' calls without getting off the couch.

UPDATE: One more annoying feature. When I am using Intercom feature - the *calling* handset rings as well. What were people thinking?! I am trying to locate a missing handset that is making faint noise from under the bed - and the ringing in my hand is louder than a rooster!

Matching the incoming call with the directory (ala cell phone), bluetooth, computer integration (for address book, CallerID, and additional ringtones).

reviewText:
My husband purchased this table for me after 3 other tables that were terrible, each in it's own way. One had no place to position my legs comfortably. Another one has casters that just refused to roll when I pushed it and the "lock" on the wheels would just lock all by itself and when I tried to push it, it would start to topple over.

This table solves many of my problems. The wheels roll easy even on carpeting. There is plenty of room for my mouse pad and mouse on the left side and on the right, I can have paper and pencils to make notes, etc. It is very easy to close the sides up and it looks just like a table. It pivots easily to get the most comfortable angle.

The only drawback is that, I have a 15.4" laptop and I had USB items plugged into the ports on both sides for my mouse (I hate the touch pad), A speaker and my cooling pad. The place where you put the laptop is a bit too narrow when I utilize the ports which are on each side of my laptop. I am now only using the ports on the left side and everything fits. I am not using my speaker right now until I find a good USB extension.

Other than that one problem it is a really good table for my laptop. You will have to take the one negative into account, if you have a laptop bigger than a 15.4"!

My printing involves documents, photos, and small flyers -- with color and brightness being very important for the latter two.  The "XL" cartridges contain more than double the amount of ink of the standard cartridge and thus will print double the number of  phlotos/flyers.  Good economics.
Further, to make the best prints & flyers requires a match between the printer, the  inks and the paper.  My recommendation is to purchase the sane brands of paper and inks as your printer.  They are technically "designed for each other".

It's been a while since I used Mod Podge, but at a recent event I was reminded of its versatility.  I bought some and keep it around for my grandchildren to do projects with.  It's got no noxious fumes, is not dangerous, and is very easy to work with.  It also cleans up easily with soap and water.  Mod Podge leaves a nice shiny surface that's hard.  You have to watch out for streaking because it's not self-leveling, but it CAN be sanded when completely dry and recoated with a thinned down, more self-leveling coat.  It's a great product.

I had an hp RX3715 iPAQ that lasted nearly five years, so I'll compare to that one.  I've used all the built-in features, especially the Calendar with its reminder feature.  Using Word was my second-most used program.  I also bought other software such as a dictionary.

A battery charge on the new iPAQ 111 doesn't last nearly as long and it takes a lot longer to recharge the battery.

It doesn't have infrared communication ability and one of the great features of my old iPAQ was its spectacular "universal remote" capability.

The volume isn't nearly as loud on the new iPAQ.  Putting it on its highest setting is about the same as medium on the old unit.

The new iPAQ's screen is much brighter than the old one.  Nice for being in the sunlight, but it uses up the battery much faster.  I set it to a dim setting because I'm usually indoors.  When I'm outside, it takes too many screen taps to access the brightness settings, which is nearly impossible when I'm in the sun and can't see the screen, so I still have to find shade (my hand isn't enough.)  They should've made one-button access to the brightness control.

The buttons on the bottom of the unit are larger, but they don't have solid space around them like my old one did.  Thus I frequently hit them with my hand while I'm writing on the screen, throwing me into some other function and losing the words I'd just written on the screen.

I am happy the new iPAQ has a commonly available USB cable.  I like that the SD slot and power button are no longer on the top.  Dirt could easily get into my first iPAQ and one of the things that gave me trouble with it was an erratic power button.  Unless you frequently remove the SD card, I suggest you put tape over it to keep dust and water out.
 The new iPAQ apparently has a feature to allow it to connect via Bluetooth to my cell phone so that I can access the Internet when I'm not in a hotspot.  I'll like this, but I haven't tried it yet, so I can't comment further on that.
 The new iPAQ is about half the size of my old one, with the same RAM, memory and screen resolution.  The old one also had a camera, but my cell phone had a better camera, so it wasn't really worth the extra $200 (but it was a lot easier to transfer photos and videos to my desktop.)
-------------------------------------
I'm having terrible trouble getting my new iPAQ to sync with my desktop, via ActiveSync.  It takes 45 minutes to synchronize whereas my old iPAQ would easily sync in five.  Then when the iPAQ is attached via the USB cable, the desktop extremely slows down with ALL software.  AND it stays that way even after I disconnect the iPAQ--I have to reboot the desktop.  Thus, I recharge the battery with the separate charger instead of the USB cable--resulting in backing up my iPAQ data less often.  I can put the iPAQ's SD card into my computer to back that data manually, but... I put an 8 Gb SD card into this new iPAQ, but it seems my hp m7070n desktop can't read SD cards larger than 2Gb--but that might be a problem with my Windows XP.
-------------------------------------
My second iPAQ has the newer Windows Mobile 6.0 version, and as so often with "latest and greatest" from Microsoft, it's primarily different for the sake of different--I have to learn how the heck to find things that aren't any better than the previous version.  Many of the changes are for the worse.  For example, when Calendar gives a reminder, I have very few "Snooze" options.  I'd GREATLY hoped the handwriting recognition would've improved in five years, but it didn't.
 I feel many of the "improvements" on Windows Mobile 6.0 was an attempt to compete with iPods and other music devices, and it still isn't as good as them.
-------------------------------------
I bought an hp foldable keyboard to go with my new iPAQ 111.  I bought it directly from hp and they told me they no longer had the tri-fold model that had been available.  (I didn't buy that tri-fold when it was available, but wish I had.  LATER, I discovered some retailers still have that smaller model.)  The new keyboard is Bluetooth only and with the way my new iPAQ eats up battery charges, and Bluetooth needs power, I have to keep the unit plugged in.  The older keyboard allows the user to run via a cable.  The new keyboard has a slide-out stand to hold the iPAQ, but it's so flimsy I'm sure it'll soon break.  Plus, the bottom of this stand is rounded and my iPAQ slips off--they should've given it a lip to actually hold the iPAQ.  The keyboard also has something to lock it in open position so we can lay it on our lap without it collapsing down between our legs.  Again, this is so flimsy that it bends and folds anyway.
-------------------------------------
I had a metal case from RhinoSkin for my PREVIOUS hp RX3715 iPAQ, but they don't have one for the model 111, so I got one from BoxWave and I'm NOT happy with it.  First, it has a clear plastic face that provides limited protection.  I'd accidentally stepped on my old RhinoSkin case, dented the face slightly, but it saved my iPAQ.  The BoxWave case wouldn't stand up to that.  Second, the clear face lets me read the screen, but I have to open the case to do any screen-touch anyway, so it's impractical.  Third, I don't like letting other people read what's popped up on my screen when I get a Calendar reminder when the iPAQ is on my belt.
  The new case makes it difficult to reach the power button when the front cover is closed and impossible when the cover is open.  It also has useless access holes in the faceplate.  The holes apparently allow me to touch various buttons, but again, I have to open the cover anyway to then use the device, so these holes only weaken the case and allow more dirt to get in.  It even has a hole just to see the "hp" logo on the iPAQ.
The belt clip isn't as good as the RhinoSkin's.  I had the same type on a cell phone I lost because the clip doesn't easily lock into place.
  Unless RhinoSkin provides a case for the iPAQ 111 soon, I plan to epoxy a metal plate over the clear plastic on the BoxWave case to make it stronger.

All considered, I liked my previous hp RX3715 iPAQ much better.

I have tried NEAT software and hardware, every Neat version since the 2nd version of the software was released.  They get worse with each release.  They are not intuitive or even basically logical. Ummmm...Receipts have decimals on them, almost without exception.  But you have to do an advanced search to search for a decimal.  And the search does not recognize any special characters.  Ummmm...why?  How idiotic do you have to be, not to understand that users need to be able to search for ANYTHING - ANYTHING - ANYTHING.  You people at Neat Works just don't think like your customers... at all.  How hard is it to understand that people use your software in a simple, logical way?  You are SO CLOSE to being a wonderful solution...but the ways that you come up short make it worse to use than not to use.  If I can't use Neat 3 on Windows 7, then I am just out of luck.  The latest Neat software is absurdly bad.  If you have more than just a few dozen receipts/documents each month, you may as well keep your filing cabinet.  Because even if you use Neat, it will fail.  You will have a catastrophic failure of hardware and/or software, and you will wish you had physical copies.  But if you are forced to keep physical backup copies, what in the hell is the software/hardware and all the labor of scanning good for?

Neat just needs to go back to the drawing board and redesign, again.  Take it from an experienced, very experienced Neat user/customer:  Neat 4 and 5 suck.  They're a disaster.  And customer service is now non-existent.  Yay.

reviewText: I am not an artist. I purchased these pencils along with an adult coloring book in hopes of relieving stress and awakening my inner artist that I have hidden away. I would have loved to have the $100 pencils but I needed a less expensive pencil to see if I enjoyed coloring. These less expensive pencils do the job. I have nothing to compare them with but they work. They are not brightly colored like magic markers. I expected more of a color range. To me some of the colors are almost identical, but for the price they do the job.

I used the Quicker Clicker line of mechanical pencils for years. They are built to last with high quality plastic and metal pieces.

Unfortunately, I learned about their greatest drawback the hard way. The metal sleeve the lead advances out of does not retract. I always carry pencils in my pocket and I did not know the metal sleeve had poked through my jeans. When I quickly moved my arm across it, the metal sleeve caught my skin and I ended up with a 4 inch rip across my forearm. The scar is slowly healing but my distaste for this pencil never will.

If you plan to leave this pencil in a jar next to your desk, it will serve you for years and you will be very happy with it. If you're like me and carry a writing utensil in your pocket, beware!!!
summary: Ouch, be careful with this one...

The positives are covered already by a lot of folks.  No need to boot the computer, dials off the contact list, etc.

But the phone is a bit dated now.  If I were using this as a main line instead of a supplement to my cell phone, I'd find an easier to use arrangement like maybe one of the newer phones or one of the adapters that allows regular phones to be plugged in it.

The physical cord connections on the Belkin are poorly thought out.  For example there are keyhole mounting slots so it can be wall mounted, but all the cords stick out the back of the phone, making that physically impossible.  Even the power cord which has a 90 degree bend is above the level of the mounts.

They give a very tall plastic attachment for desk use which eliminates any cord issues, but could easily have put any connections on the sides and made it wall mountable as well.

The software is not capable of many newer Skype features.  Contacts with more than one number only dial one of the numbers.  There's no way to select among the numbers.  You have to do the old Skype way of having a separate entry for cell, home, work, etc. for each contact.  And while Skype on the computer knows which country you're in, you have to add the + in front of manually dialed numbers.  So I keep falling into the 00 trap where I don't wait long enough and end up with 18+ instead of 1800.  A separate + key would have been great, or even if the # key was used for the plus, it would have been so much easier.

Since these features have been in Skype for a while and there's no update for this phone, it may not be possible with the hardware.  As of November 2009, Skype for the Belkin is version 1.0.1.3, dated Aug 1, 2008.

Other than the clunky usage, call quality is pretty good, although much better on the handset than the speakerphone.  I wouldn't use the speakerphone for an important call.  Overall, if you're more likely to receive calls than to call out or use this just a little, it's pretty good.  For more frequent usage, it might be worth looking for more expensive options.

2010 Update:  There has not been a software update in 2 years, so looks like there never will be.  One big problem is as of last Summer, the adapter that plugs into the outlet started emitting a very high pitched constant noise.  Not sure how to describe it, but it would be a hum if it were lower frequency.  It is barely audible, but extremely annoying and not really worth buying a new adapter.  Definitely recommend looking for some of the newer Skype phones now.

Hitherto, I had always used either Parker or Papermate ball point pens, because their ink lasts a long time, they never skip, and they never  deposit clots of ink on the paper. The ones I like most have silver-colored tops and colored bodies, and you push on a button at the top to extrude the writing part, so you never lose a cap. Their only drawback is their price and the cost of refills, which I can't always find easily in stores, either.

I was so happy with those two types of pen that I never thought of trying to find a substitute, but recently a polymer clay group I belong to had a swap involving decoratively covering pens, and Bic Round Stics were recommended as being able to withstand the temperatures (generally around 275F) involved in baking (and thus plasticizing) the polymer clay. To my great surprise, these pens write beautifully (no matter what color their barrels--though [WARNING] the "crystal"-barreled type is absolutely no good for baking)!

Voila! Gorgeous pens that write beautifully, and can be refilled really cheaply. It is true that when I cannibalize a Bic Round Stic pen to use its ink shaft as a refill in a polymer-covered pen, I use the ink from the inside, but discard and thus "waste" the pen that contained it; but even so, the price of these pens is so low that the "refills" are still incredibly cheap compared to the P'kr and PMt ones! (The only drawback to these "polymer-covered-pen swap" Bic Round Stic pens is that the clay layer makes them a bit too thick to take the original caps. No problem! When I take some covered pens with me in my bag, I simply stick them in a leather pen case thick enough to keep the points from piercing it.

For those who aren't familiar with it, polymer clay comes in many colors, which can be kneaded and blended to make more colors. It contains a plasticizer that turns it into a hard substance when baked for about 1/2 hour (usually in a toaster oven not used for food).  It makes a great hobby. There are some helpful and fun sites where people discuss its use and enjoy swaps. [...] and [...] The pen swap was at City-o-clay, and you may be able to find a link to pictures of the pens in the swap there. Have a look and get some of these great Bic Round Stic Ball Pens (with blue, silver, white, or translucent barrels--NOT the crystal ones) and make some gorgeous pens for yourself and friends.)

Or, if you don't insist on designer colors and patterns in your pens and are content with plain blue and the like, buy a bunch of these Bic pens anyway and use them as is. I don't see how anyone could fail to love the way they write or their cost!
summary: Great little pens! They write as well as expensive Parkers and Papermates.

reviewText: I like the concept of having this compact unit sitting under my desk where I use to have the corporate recycle box. The box would get taken away every now and again to be shredded. Now I can stack my papers directly in this unit and shred whenever I push the button. The speed is good! The sound is pretty quiet! Good container...can hold a descent amount of shredded paper. If everything is straight paper it works great. But. . .if the paper is wrinkled or smaller pages (smaller than 8x11) or cardstock, the auto feeder chokes. I'm left with the manual feeder which works fine for these other types of paper. So why spend $200 when all I needed is a manual feed shredder?!? Well, not worth it. Also I found I had to smash down the shredded paper often. If the pile gets too high...even a loose pile...jams start again. OVERALL: Shredding at home: I would normally shred credit card forms or any other letter / folded paper that had personal information. Since most of these are not nice 8x11 pages, then the auto feeder is pretty useless. For home use of a manual shredder the Fellowes Powershred W-11C 11 Sheet Cross-Cut Shredder (3103201) has been a great product for a fraction of the price. Thus, the auto tray is more appropriate for work where handling 8x11 pages is more common. Depending on your needs, this shredder could go really well for you or fall short.
summary: Not worth $200, but great concept otherwise

When compared to other printers, the 860 fares very well in some respects. It produces photo prints that are closest to those that you would get from store processing. It also does quite a good job with text. It merits its "best buy" status.
But is any printer really a "best buy" for photo printing when compared to photo processing? To get store-quality prints with the 860 you need Canon's best paper. And when you use that paper the prints cost far more than store processed prints, but you get nothing more for your expense than immediacy. So, if you need an instant print perhaps it is worth the extra, but the additional cost of printing from the 860 versus taking your memory card to the local store could be immense if you take a lot of photos.
In a couple of important respects the 860 prints you get even with Canon Photo Paper Pro are inferior to processed pics. If you bend the Pro paper you will not just get a crease in the paper, you will also get a pronounced line in the photo itself, and it doesn't take much of a bend to cause this. It is also very easy to scratch the surface of the prints. So, they are much more easily damaged than conventional photos. Also, the independent company that does the testing for print longevity has found that the Canon prints will only last about 25 years, while those of HP and Epson will last more than 75 years. Many people want pictures they can save for their grandchildren (or "posterity"), and the Canon prints apparently won't meet that desire.
Canon supples software that you need to utilize all print features. This consumes more time and reduces efficiency. (At least on a Mac.) Even using the printer tray, the pictures are not properly centered if you choose to have borders. There is more white space on some sides than others, so I consider that option useless.
Most people rate this printer compared to other printers. I prefer to compare it to other real-world options. In that respect it only does so-so. I prefer not to pay considerably more for prints that are no better than I can get by waiting for 60 minutes at a store, or sending them via the internet and picking them up at my leisure.

On a certain level ink is ink - how much more can you say about it?  There certainly are questions of durability, strength, permanence (also known as washability), and the tendency to bleed through a typical sheet of paper.  On those counts Sheaffer Skrip is outstanding, especially in terms of durability and strength.  What I particularly like about Sheaffer's Skrip is that it is less likely to bleed through a sheet of paper to show on the other side.  As far as washability/permanence goes, both brands can be got out by pre-treating with Simple Green or hairspray (or both).  Better still, Skrip works fine in my Sheaffer cartridge style fountain pens, but also some of the later production Esterbrook fountain pens.  And more importantly Skrip is available in a far wider variety of colors than other cartridge-style pens (and their own bottled ink!) including turquoise, purple, orange, green, and brown.  This gives writers a broader palate to express themselves, something to think about if you like writing with a little flair!  While that won't likely lead to a renaissance of fountain pens, it certainly could liven up your daily writing.  And thank heavens for online retailers, as these cartridges are getting harder and harder to find in retailers outside of stationary stores and pen shops.
summary: A great ink for great pens

What I didn't know when I was buying this binder was that there was a legal pad and calculator included (see pictures). Nice bonus, since the calculator sits perfectly in the pocket. The binder measures 12.7 inches tall, 11 inches wide, and 1.5 inches thick. It measures 22.5 inches wide when open. The binder inside is a 1 inch. The interior of the front side is lined with a pocket to stick folders that opens up about 2 inches. The outside of this pocket has 6 cardholders, 1 business card holder, 1 mesh pocket w/ velcro, and 1 calculator slot. The picture would indicate that there is a mesh business card holder, fabric pen holder, and another pocket with a zipper, but in fact, there are not. There is however, an elastic pen holder on the inside of the back cover (see picture). The back of this binder is bound with a smooth, matte plastic material, and the rest of the fabric feels like a rough nylon. As far as the false picture goes, at the time that I am writing this review, there are separate Amazon listings under different sellers that use this picture, so for all I know, the picture may be accurate for those other binders. For the one I received, it was not accurate. I bought my binder from Bison Office supply. I like this binder for a few reasons. Firstly, the zipper. It keeps everything in, so if you have an oops!-moment, you won't be embarrassed and have to scramble to pick up all your stuff. It also keeps paper edges from getting damaged and looking shabby. The zipper itself has a nice curve where you hold it that makes it easier to grip, and therefore, easier to zip. There is only one zipper on this binder, and it would be a nice extra if there were two. The zipper has a hole, so you could attach a key chain if you wanted to. The second feature I like about this binder is its slimness. It does measure about 1.5 inches rather than 1, but the binders advertised as 1.5 inches usually end up being 2. I hate unnecessarily bulky things, and at my college, we get those chairs with dinky little desk things attached, so small is a must. Furthermore, I only have the rest of my semester's notes in this at any one time. I don't need a 2 or 3 inch binder for that; the 1 inch is great for exactly that amount of notes. I also like the fact that I can keep my wireless notebook and planner inside of this. There's enough pockets for all of the things I need in a class, and I am tempted to just carry this around instead of a bag. I might even try that out. The seams on this are tight and durable. When I first received it, I realized that there was a place to put the cardboard backing of a legal pad (to hold it in place inside the binder), but not a place to put the cardboard backing of a notebook, which is what I needed this for. The main difference between these two pockets is that the insert pocket for pads is horizontal and the pocket for notebooks is vertical (see pictures). I really wish that they had included a vertical pocket behind the horizontal one, so both pads and notebooks could be secured inside. It's kind of stupid that Mead doesn't just make a pocket for it. I used my pocketknife to rip out the seam to the side of the legal pad pocket, and now my wireless notebook can be secured just as it could have if it had come made with a pocket for it (see pictures). While I was ripping, I did come across an adhesive around the seam to further secure it. This just goes as further proof to how durable the seams on this binder are. As I slid the back of my notebook in, I came across some more nasty adhesive. To remedy this, I cut the backing of my notebook down to size. On a side note that is related, I'm notorious at school for having the most tidy (and most borrowed) notes around. I'm often asked for tips. Since this binder is a key part of my note-taking system, I thought I would share: I prefer to have extra paper under whatever I'm writing on. I find it very hard to write on one piece of paper with a hard desk underneath. It doesn't give the right amount of cushion to write neatly. Plus, if I'm writing on my home desk, I don't want to scratch or put writing indents on the surface of it. I remedy this situation with a loose-leaf pad (commonly dubbed "wireless notebook" on Amazon... Norcom 3-Subject Wireless Notebook Wide Ruled, 10.5 x 8 Inches, 5 Assorted Colors, 132 Sheets, 1 Notebook per Order, Color May Vary (76132-24)). I have tried marble notebooks and I have tried spiral notebooks. Marble notebooks don't have large enough pages, and they aren't able to tear out without ruining the binding. Not to mention, you can't keep the pages in a binder or in any kind of an organized fashion after you rip them out. Spiral notebooks, on the other hand, have sharp wires that tangle with other spiral notebooks, annoyingly perforated pages that never rip where the perforation is, and leave behind tiny bits of paper that go everywhere. The solution, my friends, is a loose-leaf pad. There's a nice little place in the back of this binder where the pad will fit. I remove the pad from the binder when I have to take notes, since binders are too big for my workspace. I keep the binder under my chair until the end of class, at which time I tear out my notes and secure them into the proper section in my binder. I tab each subject with a blue tab, and each unit with a pink tab (Avery NoteTabs, 2 x 1.5 Inches, Neon Blue and Magenta, 40 per pack (16293)). I also use BIC 4-Color Ball Pen, Medium Point, 3 Pack, Assorted Ink (MMP31-ASST) to help differentiate texts. The different colored inks are useful for recording problem solving steps in math classes or writing side-notes in English classes. I try to avoid highlighting things because it looks sloppy and tends to bleed through or fade. When I finish with a semester or course and I don't need notes on hand anymore, I stow them away in a cheap, regular binder at home. I have found that this is the most pleasurable and effective way to take and keep notes.
summary: A Key Part of My Note System

After about 5 weeks we are giving up on the MagicJack and going to another Voip phone service (from our cable company). We have two major problems: (1) Getting a conversation started and in sync with the caller, (2) audio breaking up.

#1 is a problem about half the time. We answer a call but there seems to be no one on the other end. Then, after 3-4 "hellos", we begin to hear bits of a voice and after a couple more tries we seem to get in sync with the caller and can begin a normal conversation. But sometimes the caller hangs up before that can occur, because they can't hear us either.

#2 is even more serious. After a few minutes of conversation, the caller begins to complain that they cannot understand our words. It is "breaking up", like a bad cell phone connection. To the point where it is impossible to continue, so we have to hang up and call back again. That restores service for a few minutes, but the problem recurs.

I don't think it is a problem with our internet or phones - we had Vonage Voip before this and it worked great. And we have good high speed cable internet. We thought to save money using MagicJack, but for us it has been unusable. We have cancelled the service and transferring our number to the Voip phone service from our cable provider.  Somewhat more expensive, but hopefully more reliable. We would have gone back to Vonage, but we got a nice price break on a bundled cable/internet/phone package from Brighthouse.

In fairness, my sister-in-law uses MagicJack and it works fine for them (they are in a different area, though).

This is not my first Brother wireless inkjet printer. I've been using one at home for a number of years and I didn't hesitate to install this one in my office.

The pros:
1) Pretty easy to set up.
2) The footprint it great. The landscape printing means this printer takes up so much less space than comparable printers from Brother or other manufacturers.
3) Easy to install and replace the ink cartridges.
4) Easy to use touchscreen panel.
5) Generally good print quality in black & white and color.

The cons (but really more of a "heads up" than a complaint):
1) I've found the Brother printers to be a bit noisier than printers I've used from other manufacturers though not so much that I shied away from another one.  I'm just alerting those for whom this might be a problem.
2) Brother ink cartridges tend to be expensive.  I've purchased generic ones for years on-line and found no difference from the name brand. And the prices are typically so low that even if they lasted for fewer pages they would still be quite a value.  So this is a negative that I get around easily but I'm alerting those who feel comfortable using only the manufacturer's "recommended" ink cartridges.
3) I wouldn't use this product as my primary work printer. For very large jobs (printing or scanning) I use a much higher end printer that is more robust and faster but I love having this one close at hand at my desk for all those small jobs that arise throughout the day.

All-in-all a recommended printer for home use or light office use!
summary: A solid printer with a great footprint

My boss told me to grab one of these, to help "spend" some of the end of year budget, for the home office. I love it. I was a little leery to by a non-HP laserjet. The HP I was leaning towards used some kind of rotating toner holder, which as a technician, immediately set up a redflag about more moving parts than needed. This Dell was only $30 more than the HP, but also included auto-duplexing. I LOVE this printer. It's huge though, don't be fooled by the picture, it arrived in a box my kids fought for to use as a playhouse. It sits on the floor beside my desk. Too big for any home furniture. It's a good 18 x 18 footprint, really more if you want to open it up for the scanner or a paperjam. Speaking of paper jams, not a one so far, even when duplexing. My only complaint is that the networking isn't wifi. That was a big deal for me, but was easily solved with TP-LINK TL-WR700N Wireless N150 Portable Router, Pocket Design, Router/AP/Client/Bridge/Repeater Modes,150Mpbs

I experience two kinds of jams all the time with this printer. One is where the paper comes from the bottom tray to the printing section and gets stuck and crinkled behind the printer. The other is where it starts printing normally and the paper stops moving while the printer keeps printing. In either case, it does not detect a paper jam until it "finishes" printing, therefore wasting the entire page's worth of ink. So every time this happens, I waste a sheet of paper (not the biggest deal), and a page's worth of ink (big deal). It's just not acceptable when ink cartridges cost an arm and a leg. It's now going back to the store as a defective item.
summary: So much wasted paper and ink--going back to store

reviewText:
Being a Fiskars branded item I expected better quality. Sadly I don't consider this to be up to the Fiskars standard.
My biggest issue is the caps on many pens would not snap in place, making portability an issue. Originally my intent was to keep these in a small tote with my weekly-planner/art journal so that I would have a nice selection of pretty colors when I carry my journal with me, but the poor caps make that unfeasible. I will still use them, but only at my desk where I can store them in a plastic storage bin. This issue cost this rating one star.
My lesser issue is that some of them skip and I have to re-write parts of words. That is not desirable, but that in itself cost this rating one star.
But because there is a great variety of colors to choose from I give them 2 stars and because there are metallics included I give them another star.
3 out of 5 stars.

reviewText:
These are adequate file folders with an erasable writing area that is tested to work with permanent marker and white eraser. I have a thing full of pencils that I haven't used in decades and I figured maybe the eraser needs to be harder than your typical pencil eraser, and since my pencil erasers are so dehydrated I gave it a try and it worked. So there's my Heloise tip for those with decades-old pencils they might want to try...otherwise white erasers are out there.

The folders have a huge writing area, the bottom of which will be covered by standard size papers. The folders are made in the United States of thin but adequate stock, which consists of at least ten percent recycled content, that is more than capable of sitting in a file basket or organizing drawer. Manila folders are available in hundred packs for the same price, so if I use each one of these file folders four times, theoretically, I would break even monetarily.

reviewText: I like using these size labels when I need to ship internationally. The USPS customs form fits great on this size label. On the smaller 8168 labels I use for domestic the customs form is pretty much squished in there and the sharpness of the print gets messed up. I will admit that sometimes these newer Avery Labels can peel back off but I think it also depends on the surface. I've noticed that it happens more when the surface is on the glossy side. The labels work great with most boxes, Kraft bubble mailers, over other labels, and paper. The list of surfaces I'm giving are for ones I've used it on....I can't guarantee if it will work the same for you but so far I haven't had too many issues.

I have been a fan of Velcro forever. I even bought into the Velcro-closure tennis shoes thirty years ago! You just can't go wrong with 3M Velcro products. Make sure you're using these on a surface that will take the glue, and give a good wipe with rubbing alcohol to ensure there's no problem with the glue sticking. More problems with these occur when the glue lets go than when there's any issue with the Velcro part. That's not always the product's fault.

These perform exactly as you'd expect. There is no trick or secret to Velcro these days. Or maybe there is. I have been quite impressed by the newer dual-lock Velcro products for durability and strength when you need something that can connect and disconnect often with great strength.

These are so much better than trying to use normal printer paper to make binder spine inserts!  Normal paper is too thin so it just folds once you get it 2/3 of the way down the spine.  These are really thick so I didn't have any trouble pushing them all the way down.  Avery also has free software that you can download, a Microsoft Word template, or a website app that you can use to print the spines.

reviewText: We needed to mail a long thin brochure and this worked out perfectly.  It solved a problem we had worried about for quite a while.

I purchased these to do a custom coffee mug for a gift. They worked very well for this and the mugs continue to keep their design even after several (hand) washes.

The Five Star Tablet sleeve is surprisingly nice for the price range. The inside is lined with a type of micro-fleece or micro-fiber of some sort and fits a Nexus tablet without any issues. The description says this is "padded" but I highly doubt there is any actual foam padding in there beyond just a few layers of fabric. I would be cautious to casually toss this into a school bag or other heavily used bag without care being taken to avoid it being crushed or pressed against something that could damage the screen.

Advantages:
- Soft interior won't scratch the screen.
- Zipper only goes about 1/2 way around the case, keeping your device secure even when fully opened. Good for charging and offering protection while it is laying around the bedroom or house.

Disadvantages:
- The exterior mesh pocket is pretty skimpy and can barely hold my cable for the Nexus. I also don't like how much pressure it puts on the screen when I put the cable in the front pocket. It's the right size for pens and pencils, I suppose, but the pocket doesn't fully close.
- The Five Star logo on the front makes the item look very middle school-ish and cheap in my opinion. This is a good product for tossing in the purse or briefcase for transporting to work for the commute or the like, but the logo is a bit over the top.

This would be a good case for anyone who understands this product offers very little actual 'protection' for your device beyond basic scratch and debris protection. I wouldn't want to drop it or toss it in with school books where much pressure would be on the screen. If you're just wanting a basic cover, this is for you.
summary: Basic case for scratch and debris protection

I bought it, because it was cheap, and I don't mind "tinkering". It wrote right out of the box, it flexed very nicely. Then it stopped, no reason why, it just stopped. There was plenty of ink in it.  So I took it apart, ran it under water, cleaned every part that I possibly could several times.

I let it dry, and inked it. It worked for one word, then it stopped again. I tinkered with the nib, and got it to work, then it stopped again. Took it apart again, cleaned it, put it back together, inked it again, and it worked! Yay, then it didn't work. I watched the videos on youtube, and nothing seemed to get it to work again. I wanted to like it and do, when it writes. It just doesn't.

These clickers are an amazing invention for anyone who uses PowerPoint Presentations (PPTs) on a regular basis.  As a teacher, I use PPTs almost every single day of my life.  In fact, I utilize PPTs for almost every lecture I do.

Currently, I use a SMARTboard to display my presentations.  They are nice as you can draw on them and just touch the board to make the slide advance, but you are kind of tethered to the board that way.  This wireless presenter makes it easy to disconnect from the board and walk around your classroom.  This helps keep students on task during class and helps vary things a bit for you.

The layout of the remote is simple enough.  It has just the buttons you need and none of the ones that you don't.  It even has a built-in laser pointer in case you are away from the board and need to point to something in a picture or diagram.

The design is sleek and fits well in your hand.  You don't feel encumbered at all carrying it around the classroom.

Again, if you do a lot of presentations, this is the device for you.  You will not be disappointed with the freedom that it gives you.

And as I was provided with this device by the company to test it out and give you all my honest opinion, I take these reviews very seriously.  I hope it helped!

UPDATE (9/27/2016) - I can confirm that this presenter works with Windows 10 no problem!  No installation necessary - just plug and play.
summary: Sleek and easy to use presenter - Windows 10 compatible!

Ive always like Swingline staplers. Having said that. . . This one is not my favorite. Its ok, but there are a couple of others I prefer, which I will show below. This stapler has a weight of approximately 13oz. So its not super light, but then its not supposed to be. Though it shows on the box that its metal construction, thats not completely true. It part metal. It measures 7 long. It has up to 25-sheet capacity. Though this stapler can be used either on a flat surface, or by holding it in your hand. . . because its called the Optima Grip, its specifically designed for more handheld comfort. The silver version of this stapler is a bit heavier at 1# 3oz. But it has a sturdier feel. But if you really prefer holding the stapler in your hand to staple, then the one I like most is the Silver Compact model, which is a bit shorter and easier to hold in your hand. Swingline Optima Grip Silver Compact Stapler (S7087816B) If you tend to need to staple more than 25-pages on a regular basis, then the 87845 model will staple up to 40-pages. Swingline 87845 Optima Desktop Staplers, Full Strip, 40-Sheet Capacity, Silver/Black/Orange The Optima 25 has the same sort of look / feel as the 87845, but will only staple 25-sheets. . . but is very comfortable if you prefer holding the stapler in your hand. Swingline Stapler, Optima 25, 25 Sheets, Reduced Effort, Compact, Gray/Orange (66412) Finally, I HIGHLY recommend using only Swingline staples. They are much sharper than other "generic" staples. .. They won't jam. . . and for the slight bit of cost difference, they are well worth it.
summary: See review for other / better hand-held options

It's well worth it to buy the genuine Canon ink versus the generic versions. The Canon ink is of far higher quality and has never clogged my printer. I have a Pixma & love that printer. The Canon ink can be expensive, but you save money on the multi packs (usually). I would like to see multi packs though that are double color & double black instead of 1 color & 1 black. I would also like to see packs that are ink + paper for even bigger savings. You usually get a few more pictures & prints out of each ink cartridge than it says or than you think you will though. I won't take the risk of buying the generic ink because of all the reports of it affecting the function of your printer & in my experience with the genuine ink I haven't had a single quality issue.

This is our second Brother MFC Laser and it has been a bit disappointing. The print quality is great and that's about where the love ends and the like begins. The print speed is very average and not as fast as our 8350 model. The biggest issue we have, and it is one that I have worked on for hours, is the deep sleep issue. This printer will go into deep sleep and will not wake up without resetting the printer. It also loves to act like it is on out network and then BAZINGA!, it isn't. This only occurs at moments when we must have something printed immediately. So while we will keep this printer due to it's print quality, I want to OfficeSpace it on a regular basis.

Overall I was really impressed until I went to peel off the thin film & the mini chalkboard came right off the card & fell on my lap.  There are a mere two little thin strips of double sided tape that keep the board attached to the card.  I pressed the board back onto the card forcefully & it seems to be holding.  The board itself is made of wood so it could be removed & used for a kid or adult to play with without having to deal with the card if that's what you want to do or display it in some way.
Note:  If you plan to mail this to someone, you will need to pack it in a padded envelope with extra postage.

We got this printer as a back-up printer to our larger laser all-in-one.  When the larger printer went off-line due to a bad toner cartridge I switched to the Brother to finish a print job.  I was attempting to manual duplex print a 500 page document 100 pages at a time which is actually 50 pages 'odd' numbers, then 50 pages of 'even' numbers.  The printer got a little break after every 50 pages while it waited for me to flip the printed pages and insert them into the paper tray.  The print job was almost finished when I heard a loud "POP" sound come from the printer.  I jumped up to investigate and found the printer dead with a thin cloud of smoke drifting away from it.  I pulled out the USB cable first and when I touched the A/C power cord it nearly burned my fingers.  I used my sleeve to grip the plug and remove it from the power outlet.  The power cord was plugged into a UPS which had not tripped and did not show any evidence of an overload.  This printer was hardly ever used over the couple of years it has been in the office on standby.  Now the first time we ask it to step up and do a real job it explodes out of warranty.  Does anyone want a brand new still sealed toner cartridge?
summary: POS blew up the first time I sent it a large print job

To address various things I see coming up in other reviews: I ordered these and just got them. NO DUPLICATE COLORS in my box (not even black or white; I did receive metallic gold and metallic silver), no visibly broken pencils, no damaged pencils (well, okay, *one* had some dents on one part, but no big deal). NO EXTRAS like color blending sticks (nor did the product description promise any, at least not at the time I made my purchase). Package had adequate protection/padding (lots of those bubble-wrap blobs), and they came in just six days.

As for the quality of the product, overall... I know from prior experience that PrismaColor Premier pencils are great. They blend well and look beautiful.

Unfortunately, they do have the problem of the core breaking too much, which is frustrating. I'm not sure it can be avoided, though, since they are soft core pencils, after all. To me what's worse is when one of the cores is off center, and it's just a disaster trying to sharpen it, as the lead keeps breaking AND big chunks of the wood keep splitting off. These look alright in that respect but of course I can't be sure yet. And that's rare, anyway (maybe 1 in 30 pencils is like that). If you want something harder, try the Verithin. I don't think the occasional broken core means the pencils are a bad product, and especially  not when they're been shipped.
summary: no duplicates, no broken ones, appear to be the real deal, no issues

At $400 I can't see why anyone would buy an inkjet printer rather than a color laser printer.  On a positive note, this seems like a great design for a light duty inkjet printer.  Only time will tell if the ink works long term though.  Previous inkjet printers constantly were having quality issues and needed cartridges replaced frequently.

I like the little color display, much nicer than a boring B&W LCD screen.

I give Epson kudos for having a decent system for entering your wireless password without an actual keyboard, this is much easier than previous designs I've used.

Set up was fairly easy.  I really like the design for the ink, but beware this approach does mean that it is fairly easy to spill ink on your fingers.  Print quality seems typical of an inkjet.

Beware: it only works on a wireless network that supports 2.4GHz (which I assume almost all do) (or you could use a USB cable)  I still think Epson should include a hard wired network port for those that don't want to use wireless (but want it further away than a USB cable would work).

If you are used to having a personal scanner, this is really nice to have a networked scanner for light duty usage by all computers in the house.

Update: The printer worked nicely for several months.  But when/if it loses power it seems to lose the WiFi connection (which is a royal annoyance if your password is secure and hard to type).  Now I can't get it to connect at all (even though the network status sheet prints out that everything is fine and connected).  So I'm stuck with a printer that reports that it can't connect ("Communications Error") and nothing seems to help.  Epson's website basically says they have updated to a newer security certificate and will no longer connect from WinXP. I've been unable to find any info from Epson.  My next step is to try and delete the driver and re-install it on my computer.
GREAT AND GREAT PRICE

reviewText:
These 3 inch by 3 inch classic post-it note pads are very good for making brief notes to yourself--or, of course, notes to other people. Despite the fact that people these days often use their computer calendars to remind them of appointments and things to do, these note pads remain good sellers in stores--which is great proof that they work! Just write your note and use the adhesive on the top of the back to attach your note in the place where it needs to be seen!

Unfortunately, however, the adhesive sticky substance on the reverse of the post-it note is not as strong as I would like it to be. All too often these notes loose their ability to stay stuck in the right place until people who need their reminders can use them. I probably wouldn't use this product on a refrigerator for days at a time--it could well simply fall off and flutter right on in under the fridge! Even on flat surfaces this has been a problem.

This is a great product but obviously I cannot ignore the flaw that I just told you about. I give it three and one-half stars for being good and useful--but not great. The manufacturer needs to strengthen the adhesive portion on the reverse of the post it notes.
summary: Very good for making notes to yourself and others--but the adhesive on the back isn't strong enough

This is the smallest set of the Prisma Color Watercolor sets. The pencils blend beautifully with water, and create fantastic designs. They blend with alcohol and water. I recommend getting a much larger set for your artwork. I feel that for the price range these are the best, but if Price is not an issue recommend Albrect Durers by Faber Castell. These will blend with your other Prisma Pencils. They will work in coloring books if you are using blending markers like Copic or Spectrum Noir so that the water doesn't mess up non water color paper. Or I suggest printing onto water color paper your design of choice. You can also try putting a thin gesso over coloring book pages to water color with, but you will need to learn to apply gesso in a delicate way. For artist sketches, and water color journals these are awesome. I do feel that Prismacolor has quality control issues that are well known in the art community at this point, and hope that they can get their pencils back to their former premium states so we don't have broken lead, and cracking wood. The colors are extremely bright and beautiful, and are easily layered. I would recommend these.

reviewText:
I am an accountant, and do a considerable number of Tax Returns.  I use only Xerox 4200 paper, in all of my machines.  I have  a couple of OfficeJet Pro units, as well as a Photosmart, and a my old workhorse an HP 4000 Laser.  I have very little trouble in the way of jams, although, I have serviced the LaserJet with new rollers.  The only problem is sometimes, depending upon the moisture of the paper, I will have a failure to feed with the LaserJet.  The thing is over 15 years old, and the problem only began last year.  It seems to have started with a particular toner cartridge that I had in and replacing that one may have corrected the problem.  We shall see.

Other wise, the 4200 has been a very consistent product, takes the print well, holds up for years, as I am now going through 15 year old files, and the paper looks like new, actually the old stuff looks shiner, brighter and crisper than the new!  Maybe I should take away a couple of stars!  Nah!  I am too old to change now!
summary: and the paper looks like new, actually the old stuff looks shiner

I wanted to start a Journal for my Granddaughter. Of course I've kept diaries in the past, such as my teenage years, but I wanted this one to be special. I ended up buying 3 more the day after receiving the first one! It's PERFECT! I read the other customer reviews about which pens work best with the paper in this Journal, and I immediately ordered a bunch of the Pilot G-2 pens (based on another customer's review), and these pens work best (my "ordinary" pen was smudging in the Journal). The pages are nice (I think there're 250 pages per book), the ones I purchased (large) are the perfect size I want (they fit in my handbag), and the Journal itself is just wonderful...no gimmicky look, no teen-ager-y locks, just a plain, sleek-looking Journal. If you're thinking of starting a Journal, or even using this as a store list or To-Do list keeper, I'd highly recommend the Moleskine large.

Why did I wait so long to get one of these?  I have other Lifetime tables, but I never thought about getting one of these until ...

I use a computer stand/table in the living room so I can watch television and just have a better outdoor view (the view from my office isn't great, and my living room window overlooks a park-like yard).  I've been using a much fancier (and more expensive) "computer stand" for a couple of years, but it finally bit the dust (the weld that holds the desktop onto the central support column failed).  So I started the search for a replacement, one that maybe wasn't so fancy but would last longer.

Of course I came to Amazon -- they have everything! -- and found a number of options.  This looked like the best fit, so I ordered it.

I'm absolutely thrilled with it.  Seriously, it's even better than I expected, even with my experience with Lifetime tables (which has been excellent).  This little table is the PERFECT size for my laptop, a mug of coffee, and a couple of other items (reading glasses, etc.).  It's lightweight enough that I can easily scoot it out of the way when I need to move around (get a coffee refill, etc.).  My only quibble is that I wish it came in black, but that's absolutely NOT a deal breaker.

This feels far more stable than my old computer stand even when it was new, and it's not likely to have any similar problems.  I love that I can adjust the height, too.

Overall, this is a solid 5-star item.  Would happily purchase again if the need arises.

I purchased this on an Amazon deal, and paid a little over $80... I have been using an HP 4680 all-in-one (Color Printer, Scanner, Copier, and Fax) for over four years, and was was looking at something that would save on the cost of ink, and also as a back-up if the HP took a turn for the worse. I don't use the color often, so that was not a big issue when purchasing a printer, but wanted something that would connect to a network, either hard wired or with wi-fi. I'm not a computer engineer, but can set up most computer and electronic items with little difficulty, but I did have a some difficulty with this printer. I have not used a USB cable for years, and could not locate one, so I went straight to the wi-fi setup. For some reason, I could not get the printer or my router to communicate fully, so I connected by a LAN cable directly, and was up and running within minutes. The entire process, with my wireless issues, was around thirty minutes, but would have been only minutes had I used the LAN cable initially, probably much quicker had I located a USB cable. I use a D-Link DIR-655 Extreme-N Gigabit Wireless Router, which is near the printer, and although I've used the printer wireless, I have chosen to keep it hard wired to the router. I have five notebooks that are in use in my house, and the wireless printing is fairly fast. Once a print job is submitted, the printer takes a few seconds to warm up from a sleep mode, and has the first page out within ten to fifteen seconds, with subsequent pages within two to three seconds if printing single sided. I use the duplex mode, in an effort to save on paper, and find it takes a little longer, but far quicker than my inkjet printer. I don't find it to be an issue, but the printer is a little noisy, but quiter than most laser printers. The only major issue I've had is printing envelopes. I believe others mentioned this also, as it tends to wrinkle the envelope, which I believe is partly due to the heat, but also an issue with the rollers it seems. This is not a deal breaker, as I don't print more than a few envelopes a month, but if you were printing dozens or hundreds of envelopes a month, another printer should be considered. I've also noticed a slight curl in the paper when using the duplex mode, but that is not a permanent issue with the prints. Pros - - Fast printing through a network - Multiple connection options (USB, Wi-Fi, LAN) - Automatic 2-sided printing - Excellent printing quality - Good value for the money - Size, requires minimal space Cons - - Wrinkles in paper when printing envelopes - Limited to B/G wireless networking - Slight curl when using duplex mode Overall, for the price, this printer does a great job. I have been using the printer now for over a month, and would consider purchasing another one if I needed a printer. I have probably only printed 100 - 200 pages so far, and understand the initial toner cartridge is only rated at 700 pages, but will be replacing it with the high yield cartridge when the time comes. I expect this printer, with the cost of the printer and toner, to pay for itself within six to nine months with savings in ink cartridges alone. UPDATE 2-26-13: I've been using this printer for over six months now. When replacing the toner cartridge, which the original cartridge lasted far longer than I expected, I went with a generic replacement. I wrote a review on that, and have had no problems with it. I've run over 3,000 pages on the printer, with no issues. In fact, with what I paid for the printer and the replacement toner cartridge, I have more than saved on buying ink for my ink printer. I still use my multifunction ink printer, as it scans, faxes, copies, and prints in color, but it gets less than 5% of the total use, with this printer getting over 95% use. I have had the printer connected to the network, and no computer has had issues with printing to it, and the printer has always begun printing within ten seconds of executing print on the computer. Since my initial review, I upgraded to a WD My Net N900 HD Dual Band Router Wireless N WiFi Router Accelerate HD and have had no issues with the connection and the printer. As I stated, I have already paid for this printer in the amount I have saved in ink alone, and the quality is very good. I still recommend this to anyone wanting a network printer, for a reasonable price, that will be economical in the long run.

I got a horrific case of poison ivy a couple months ago, and after recovering I bought this.

Now I use this product AND I also now wear long pants, a long sleeve shirt, and gloves, and I'm very careful to not wipe my face while working.  As soon as I'm done working I take a hot shower and scrub like crazy, and I wash all my clothes in very hot water.  Before I wasn't nearly as careful.

I haven't gotten poison ivy since doing all of this.  I do think a large part of the protection is from fully covering myself and washing right afterward, but I do think the Ivy Block does really help.  I put it all over my hands and arms, and on my legs below the knee.  My hands do feel a bit odd after putting it on--remember doing pottery at summer camp and afterward you'd sort of wash your hands but after they dried you'd still have clay residue on them?  It's a lot like that.

But like I say, I think the stuff works.  And considering that it's $15 for two bottles and a bottle will last for a year of occasional yard work, and considering that a case of poison ivy hurts like holy #@%(*@ and you're going to pay $20 to see a doctor and $20 for the prednisone to cure it, the Ivy Block is a great deal.  I recommend it.

reviewText:
I purchased this printer due to wanting a printer without any "extras" like a scanner or fax, and originally gave it four stars. That review has been deleted after owning it for an extended amount of time and seeing how invasive the software has become over that time.

The problem is how intrusive the software is--five applications run in the background at all times. There are "HP Solution Center" pop-up reminders to buy new ink, pop-ups when printing, frequent updates to download due to what must have been faulty software, etc. I also began receiving regular advertisement e-mails from HP. The on-screen pop-ups go over any application you are currently working on, and interrupt it. The download updates seem to be necessary, because my computer and the printer frequently "lost their connection," with the computer being unable to access the printer--it often either would not work at all, or prints blank pages. This appears to be a fault on the HP side, since their updates for this printer usually list connectivity as what they are trying to improve upon. For someone on dial-up, the updates are unrealistically large. A recent update was 27 megs, took 1 1/2 hours to download, then indicated it was corrupt and the download had failed.

Eventually I uninstalled the software package, and then reinstalled only the basic software through custom install. Since then, it has operated more like a normal printer.

On the plus side, this printer has an option for higher ink capacity, with "xl" version cartridges available (though they're rather expensive). The on-deck gauge of ink levels is really a nice feature.
summary: Liked at first, but software becomes invasive

reviewText:
This is my first fountain pen.  So far, I like it.  No one is going to mistake it for some of the Pelikan M800s floating around the office, but this pen only costs 5% of the M800.  Okay, 6% if I include the price of the converter.  The Pelikan is a little smoother, but not enough to justify the $550 difference.

If you have good paper, this pen will work just fine.  However, if you have cheap, absorbent paper like we do at my office, you might want to consider getting the extra-fine nib. Fortunately, this is one of the few pens where you can buy & swap nibs separately from the pen itself.  I ended up ordering an extra-fine nib from Goulet Pens shortly thereafter, along with some quality paper and ink.

I've been impressed with how the pen handles extremes as well.  So far it's been taken from a 55F building and put directly into a 160F Florida car interior.  NO ink leakage.  It also starts writing almost immediately no matter the conditions I've put it though.  I also haven't had a problem with the case deforming from the extreme heat from inside my car.
summary: Great starter pen, probably a great all-around pen.

There are times when I have an item that I just know someone else in the world is looking for and off it goes to eBay or Craigslist. It comes in three parts...the external display (which makes it easy to read the result because it is movable and brightly lit) with included AAA batteries (can also use AC with included adapter), the scale and a cable that connects the two. Not much more to say, you put the item on the scale and read the result (lb/oz/kg/g). I compared the results to another Smart Weigh scale as shown in the video. I must say I was surprised that they were not the same. This product came in lower every time. Not sure which one was off, but I'm guessing it was this one. I am impressed that it can weigh up to 110 lbs! The scale comes with a 10 year limited warranty. This is a great small color laser printer for any home user or student. I upgraded from a Monochrome Wireless Laser printer (a Brother HL-2170W) and there are a few things that I like both about this one and the Brother wireless laser printers.

The Good things about the Samsung CLP-315W are that

- It has Wireless WPA/WPA2 with AES
- It gives you the option of having it hooked up to your router, computer, or let it be completely wireless
- I quickly found the latest drivers on Samsungs website and installed them on my computers very easily
- The Cost of the printer is pretty low compared to other color laser printers, depending on where you buy it.

The things I feel that could be improved about the Samsung CLP-315W are that:

- The manual doesnt really explain that much, it doesnt even tell you that there is already toner inside the printer, if you need to remove any safety platics from the printer before it starts printing, or how to replace the toner cartridges when they run out.

- Replacement toner will be expensive when it runs out but thats true for all laser toner.

- The design of the paper holding tray is very mediocre, it can only hold a small amount of paper and it sticks out of the printer. The design on my old Brother HL-2170W was far better, you would put all the paper in a tray that slid inside the printer and it could hold much more paper.

I would recommend the Samsung CLP-315W if you could get it at a good price, I got mine for $130 shipped.
summary: Great Wireless Color Laser Printer for light/medium duty use.

For many years, I've been storing bank statements in a standard 2 inch white binder with round rings.  The cover material is not PVC free and ink from the bank statements has adhered to both undersides of the front and back covers.  Furthermore, the binder has become stuffed to overflowing.  I can't comfortably squeeze any more bank statements inside.  Thankfully, the Amazon Vine Program offered me the Avery Nonstick Heavy-Duty EZD Reference View 2 Inch White Binder.

  I also own an Avery View SlantRing 1 1/2 inch White Binder in which I store computer related documents.  I can safely vouch that Avery makes very durable binders that last a long time.  I posted a digital photograph depicting three binders together; it mainly depicts the differences in their rings.  The Avery binder in the left of the photograph has the 2 inch EZD rings, the standard binder in the middle has the 2 inch round rings and the Avery binder in the right has the 1 1/2 inch slant rings.

  The Avery Nonstick Heavy-Duty EZD Reference View 2 Inch White Binder would make a great album dedicated to the memory of a departed loved one.  The cover material is PVC Free.  One can put a photograph of a loved one inside and not worry that it will be ruined.  Also, I like that the ink from the pages won't adhere to the undersides of the front and back covers.  At work, I am constantly having to tear pages off the covers where the ink from my directives has stuck to them.  You definitely don't want this to happen to important letters, post cards and other souvenirs and mementos from departed loved ones.  You want to preserve your memories intact for as long as possible.

  The ONE TOUCH EZD Rings make it easier for the elderly and infirm to open the binder.  The four pockets (two in the front and two in the back inside covers) in lieu of the normal two pockets makes it easier to store booklets, pamphlets, notes, etc.  I have posted a digital photograph of the notebook with four of my computer booklets inside the pockets.  The binder covers are extra wide so that dividers don't stick out.  I have downloaded and posted the product description that was inserted into the front cover.  It provides a listing of all its attributes compared to the other type binders.

  I transferred all the bank statements from my standard 2 inch binder into the Avery Nonstick Heavy-Duty EZD Reference View 2 Inch White Binder.  I must honestly say that there isn't much room for many more statements.  I will have to either reuse my beat up standard 2 inch binder or remove the bank statements from the new Avery binder and put them back into the old standard one and use the new Avery one for future storage.  I hate to use the expensive new Avery binder for storing bank statements, receipts, classroom notes, etc., that should be eventually destroyed.  The Avery Nonstick Heavy-Duty EZD Reference View 2 Inch White Binder is more appropriate for serving as a scrapbook for safely storing the cherished memories of a loved one whether they are alive or departed.

Joseph B. Hoyos
summary: Makes A Great Scrapbook For Storing Precious Mementoes That You Don't Want Damaged By Time

We were in love with this printer when we first purchased it.  It broke within three months (continued to report that there was no paper loaded, despite there being plentiful paper there).  HP was good about replacing it promptly.  It prints text FAST.  The problem is getting to the point that it has started printing.  As others have mentioned, it takes this printer eons to initialize.  Sometimes, it even decides to reset at completely random times.  And the noise...you'd think it was about to spew plastic and metal parts out the paper hole with the intensity of churning and grinding you hear.  Then there is the continued "finickiness" with regard to loading paper.  You've got to position it just right or suffer the blinking "paper out" light.

And then there is the ink.  As others have mentioned, there was a class action suit against HP because they didn't make it clear how ink was used by certain printers.  This causes most users to go through their colored ink faster than they should.  For example, with this printer, even though you may be printing a simple black and white text document, you have to click through four settings (Properties/Features/Print in grayscale/Black Ink Only) to ensure that no colored ink is used in printing your simple black and white document.

The things this printer gets right (solid wireless performance straight out of the box and fast printing) are vastly overshadowed by all the hassle we've had to go through to get things done.

Again, as others have mentioned, HP denies all allegations yet has settled the suit.  Because of my personal experience with this "feature", we will be avoiding HP products in the future.
summary: Most Annoying Printer We've Ever Owned

I've had this printer for a while now, and was pleased enough to convince my mom to buy the same one.  Very good print quality, and decent speed.  Where these guys say 6 minutes for a print job to get to the printer, sounds really way off to me!  Is it in their network/spooling?  Can't be the printer.
We've had no problems at all, ever, with feeding paper, and I've gone through immense quantities of it.  Cheap to run.
Minor complaint:  The standard font(s) seem to be less bold than some other printers.  Courier, for example, looks as if the characters are a bit "thinner" on ink than other printers give.
Long term complaint:  I found that the print quality goes down drastically, some say after moving the unit uncarefully without removing the drum/toner, though it didn't seem to be the cause for us.  This was never a problem with mom's, only mine, which admittedly was moved more and used more.  It took a REAL good cleaning of the entire drum unit, sloshing it down with alcohol-soaked rags, including meticulous cleaning of the entire green print drum.  It prints as good as new again.  Whether I'll have to repeat the cleaning later, I don't know.
But would I buy another Brother printer?  Without a doubt, yes!
summary: Nice printer, grainy late in life

For those looking for the differences between the S1100 vs S1100i, there are three main differences after doing some research.  Not much info on the net about this.  The S1100 can do duplex scanning, which the S1100i cannot do.  The S1100i however can do Dual-Scan (scan multiple small documents at the same time such as receipts AND extract that information from them) and Scan Stitching which will stitch together multiple large pages.  So it really comes down to this, if you are scanning multiple dual sided documents, go with the S1100, if you are scanning more receipts/ business cards, photo back-up, general scanning, go with the S1100i.

Be aware that these labels come only one per sheet, covering the top half the sheet, with plain paper at the bottom which is intended for a receipt.  There may be instances when a paper receipt might be desired, but shipping information is kept online by the USPS and eBay and others, so only those who need a paper receipt should buy these labels.

These are designed for use for eBay shipping, USPS Click-N-Ship service, pbSmartPostage, and Stamps.com (the latter is mentioned in the instructions on the back of the label but not on the box). Avery supplies Design & Print and MS Word templates on their web site.  Avery advises using the templates for their 5127 labels and warns that if you're shipping UPS, you should feed the labels with the receipt first.

They are designed for BOTH inkjet and laser, which is nice.  On the shipping web page, there is usually a checkbox for which you can choose a receipt or not.

After peeling off the label, the receipt can be separated at a perforation.  The perfs are a  little stubborn and it would be nice if they were easier to separate.

Lets compare costs: These 27900 labels are 38 cents each (for 100 labels) and 20 cents (for 500 labels). The inkjet label Avery 8126 has 2 labels per sheet for 16 cents per label (for 50 labels).  The 5126 version (laser) has 2 labels per sheet for 11.5 cents (for 200 labels).  So you're paying almost twice as much to be able to print the receipt.

Another factor is the label stock itself: there is some show-through because the labels are relatively thin, while the 8126 and 5126 labels have TrueBlock technology which uses a more opaque material so that it covers any printing under the label.

Adhesive quality is good and the labels fed properly through my laser printer from both the tray or manual feed.  The laser printing did not rub off.

Buy these is you really need the receipt. Otherwise, get the 2-label per sheet ones and save some money.
summary: One label per sheet - somewhat pricey

reviewText:
Update .... once again Okitalk is supported by Google Voice ...

We got fed up with the rising costs of our land-line with monthly fees going over $70. We heard about free Google Voice and discovered that this modem was the best choice to use with Google Voice. Easy setup ... just remember you will need a second working land line or cell number to confirm Google Voice. What attracted us to this modem has the two phone ports for two different numbers and fax capability. Free fax? Could not be beat! Using Winfax on a Windows XP Sony Vaio as well as with a second Sony Vaio with Windows 7 Home Premium using Windows FAX capability. I was also able to FAX through my Canon MF4350D Image Class printer through the Okitalk modem when I could no longer use Winfax on my Windows 7 PC. Any questions we had were responded to within 8 to 12 hours. Very polite and professional. Voice quality is clear for the most part. You will get the typical VOIP latency which at times will make it seem like you are cutting people off. Latency depends on the connection as well ... most of my local calls were fine. Much better than our former land line with ATT. There are some connections that drop off and some that you may have to redial but these are more of an issue with Google Voice.
summary: Google Voice supports Okitalk again September 2014
